diseases.summary: Acoustic neuroma is a benign tumor that develops on the vestibulocochlear nerve, which connects the ear to the brain. It typically grows slowly and can press against the hearing and balance nerves, leading to symptoms like hearing loss, tinnitus, dizziness, and balance problems. If it grows large enough, it can press against the brainstem and become life-threatening. It can also cause facial numbness or paralysis. In some cases, acoustic neuromas are associated with a genetic disorder called neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).
causes: malfunction of schwann cells that form the insulating myelin sheath on the vestibulocochlear nerve
mutation in the tumor suppressor gene, nf2, located on chromosome 22, resulting in abnormal production of the cell protein merlin
risk_factors: therapeutic radiation exposure to the head
symptoms: loss of hearing on one side
feeling of fullness in the affected ear
diagnosis: computed tomography (ct scan) of the head
treatments: medical therapies (clinical trials for drugs like everolimus, lapatinib, mifepristone)

diseases.summary: Tonsillitis is an inflammation of the tonsils, which are lumps of tissue at the back of the throat that are part of the lymphatic system. It can be caused by viral or bacterial infections.
symptoms: white or yellow coating on tonsils
diagnosis: physical examination of throat and neck

diseases.summary: Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) is a rare type of cancer that can occur in various body sites, most commonly in the salivary glands. It is the third-most common malignant salivary gland tumor overall and the most common malignant salivary gland tumor in the submandibular gland region. ACC is generally well-differentiated and slow-growing, allowing patients to survive for years with metastases, though late-occurring metastatic disease can lead to death.
causes: myb gene fusion with the nfib gene due to t(6;9) translocation
myb activation by copy number gain
myb activation by juxtaposition of enhancer elements near the myb gene
fusion of the mybl1 gene to nfib or other partners
diagnosis: mri-images analyzed following nerve tracts up to the brainstem
treatments: fast neutron therapy (for advanced, inoperable, recurrent, or gross residual disease)
chemotherapy (for metastatic disease, on a case-by-case basis)

diseases.summary: Malignant tumors of the adrenal glands, which are located on top of each kidney and produce essential hormones like sex hormones and cortisol. Most adrenal gland tumors are benign and do not cause symptoms or require treatment. Adrenal gland cancers are uncommon.
symptoms: symptoms depend on the type of cancer

diseases.summary: Adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) is an aggressive and rare cancer originating in the cortex (outer part) of the adrenal gland, which produces vital hormones like sex hormones and cortisol. It often presents with various hormonal syndromes due to steroid hormone-producing tumors, and can invade nearby tissues or metastasize to distant organs. The disease has a bimodal age distribution, affecting children under 5 and adults between 30-60, with women more frequently affected. The overall 5-year survival rate is about 50%.
causes: inherited inactivation mutation in tp53 gene
risk_factors: family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia (men)
family history of familial adenomatous polyposis
diagnosis: increased serum glucose (laboratory finding for cushing's syndrome)
increased urine cortisol (laboratory finding for cushing's syndrome)
excess serum androstenedione (laboratory finding for virilism)
low serum potassium (laboratory finding for conn syndrome)
low plasma renin activity (laboratory finding for conn syndrome)
high serum aldosterone (laboratory finding for conn syndrome)
excess serum estrogen (laboratory finding for feminization)
differential diagnosis from renal cell carcinoma
subtypes: primary bilateral macro nodular adrenal hyperplasia (bilateral)

diseases.summary: Anal cancer is a type of cancer that forms in the tissues of the anus, the distal opening of the gastrointestinal tract. It is most commonly a squamous cell carcinoma and is strongly associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. Symptoms often include bleeding, lumps, pain, itching, discharge, and changes in bowel habits. Diagnosis typically involves physical exams, DRE, anoscopy, and biopsy, while treatment usually combines chemotherapy and radiation therapy, sometimes with surgery.
causes: human papillomavirus (hpv) infection (especially high-risk types like hpv-16)
risk_factors: weakened immune system (e.g., due to hiv/aids or organ transplant medicines)
symptoms: bleeding from the anus or rectum
pain in the area around the anus
pressure in the area around the anus
change in bowel habits (e.g., narrower stools, increased frequency, bowel incontinence)
diagnosis: medical history (including symptoms and family health history)
anal pap smears (for screening high-risk individuals)

diseases.summary: Anaplastic thyroid cancer (ATC) is a rare, aggressive form of thyroid cancer characterized by uncontrolled growth of highly abnormal cells in the thyroid gland. It accounts for a small percentage of thyroid cancer cases but is responsible for a significant proportion of deaths due to its aggressive behavior, rapid growth, and resistance to many standard cancer treatments. ATC typically carries a very poor prognosis, with a median survival time of three to six months after diagnosis. It often presents as a rapidly enlarging neck mass and can cause symptoms by compressing local structures.
risk_factors: exposure to certain types of radiation (e.g., radiation treatments to head or neck as a child, radiation emergency, repeated radiation exposure to chest or neck)
certain genetic conditions (e.g., multiple endocrine neoplasia)
family history of thyroid cancer or thyroid disease
symptoms: redness and swelling of overlying skin
diagnosis: physical exam (checking neck for swelling, lumps)
immunohistochemistry testing (e.g., positive for keratin, p53, pax8; negative for thyroid transcription factor-1, thyroglobulin, calcitonin)
ultrasound imaging (hypoechoic mass, invasion of local structures, lymph node metastases)
contrast-enhanced computed tomography (ct) scan of the neck
ct scan of the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis (for staging)
magnetic resonance imaging (mri) of the brain (to assess for distant metastases)
treatments: surgery (often unresectable, but curative if resectable and followed by adjuvant therapy)
combinatorial therapy (molecular-based, targeted therapies, immunotherapy, surgery)

diseases.summary: Angiosarcoma is a rare and aggressive cancer originating in the endothelial cells that line blood or lymphatic vessels. It can appear anywhere in the body, but is most commonly found in older individuals and frequently affects the skin, particularly the scalp. The disease often presents with non-specific symptoms or can be asymptomatic, and multiple-organ involvement is common at the time of diagnosis. It is known for its high metastatic potential and poor prognosis.
causes: damage to the dna of endothelial cells, leading to uncontrolled cell division and inhibited programmed cell death (underlying causes of dna damage are not fully understood)
symptoms: superior vena cava syndrome (complication of cardiac angiosarcoma)
diagnosis: absence of s100 marker (for differentiation from melanoma)
absence of hmb-45 marker (for differentiation from melanoma)

diseases.summary: Appendix cancer is a very rare malignant tumor that forms in the vermiform appendix. It encompasses various tumor types, including carcinoids and adenocarcinomas, and can lead to conditions like Pseudomyxoma peritonei.
causes: metastasis from tumors of the female genital tract
risk_factors: older age (4th to 5th decades for carcinoids)
female sex (minor prevalence for neuroendocrine tumors)
caucasian ethnicity (minor prevalence for neuroendocrine tumors)
diagnosis: pathological examination of biopsy or resected tissue

diseases.summary: Astroblastoma is a rare glial tumor derived from astroblasts, primarily found in the supratentorial region of the brain but can occur in other brain areas like the cerebellum, optic nerve, cauda equina, hypothalamus, and brain stem. It accounts for a small percentage of brain gliomas and is considered challenging to diagnose and treat among nervous system cancers.

Astrocytoma is a type of brain tumor originating from star-shaped glial cells called astrocytes, primarily in the cerebrum, and occasionally in the spinal cord. It is the second most common glioma and typically does not spread outside the central nervous system. Astrocytomas are graded from I to IV based on malignancy, with low-grade types often found in children and young adults, and high-grade types more prevalent in adults.
causes: homozygous deletion of cdkn2a/b (main feature of high-grade astrocytoma)
genome-wide pattern of dna copy-number alterations (cnas)
risk_factors: childhood or young adulthood (for low-grade types)
young people (for astrocytomas in the base of the brain)
symptoms: headache that goes away after vomiting
diagnosis: tests of vision, balance, coordination, and mental status
neuropathologist examination (for atypical cells, new blood vessel growth, mitotic figures)
subtypes: subependymal giant cell astrocytoma (who grade i)

synonyms: Malignant Rhabdoid Tumor of the CNS
diseases.summary: Atypical Teratoid Rhabdoid Tumor (AT/RT) is a rare, aggressive, Grade IV cancerous tumor primarily affecting the central nervous system (CNS) in infants and young children. It commonly occurs in the brain, especially the posterior cranial fossa, but can also be found in the spinal cord. AT/RT is characterized by specific genetic mutations, particularly deletions or mutations in the INI1/hSNF5 gene, and has a historically poor prognosis, though multimodal therapy has shown improved survival rates.
risk_factors: family history of at/rt or other rhabdoid tumors
symptoms: headache (especially morning headache or headache that resolves after vomiting)
abnormal feeling in the legs (spinal tumor)
diagnosis: imaging (mri of brain and spine, ct of chest and abdomen)
lumbar puncture (to check for m1 disease)
pathological examination (cytological or genetic analysis of tumor tissue)
cytogenetic studies (e.g., fluorescent in situ hybridization)
treatments: chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatinum, carboplatinum, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, etoposide, ifosfamide, mafosfamide)
high dose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue
radiation therapy (e.g., upfront radiation, conformal local radiation, external beam radiation, proton beam radiation)
multimodal therapy (combination of surgery, chemotherapy, radiation)
chromatin remodeling agents (histone deacetylase inhibitors - preclinical)

diseases.summary: Basal-cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer, often appearing as a painless, raised, shiny skin area with small blood vessels or ulceration. It grows slowly, can damage surrounding tissue, but rarely spreads to distant areas or results in death.
causes: sun exposure (leading to dna damage like thymine dimers)
depressed local immune system (due to sunlight)
risk_factors: lighter skin, hair, and eye color
geographic location (closer to equator or higher altitudes)
symptoms: painless, raised, shiny skin area with small blood vessels
loss of sensation (if impinging on nerves)
loss of function (if impinging on nerves)

diseases.summary: Cholangiocarcinoma, also known as bile duct cancer, is a rare type of cancer that forms in the bile ducts, which are tubes that carry bile from the liver to the small intestine. It can occur in bile ducts inside or outside the liver.
causes: infection with liver flukes (opisthorchis viverrini, clonorchis sinensis)
risk_factors: congenital liver malformations (e.g., caroli disease, choledochal cysts)
chronic liver disease (including viral hepatitis, alcoholic liver disease)
altered dna repair functions in inflammatory bowel disease patients
gut microbiota and bile acid activity
symptoms: jaundice (yellowish skin, yellowing of eyes and skin)
abnormal liver function tests (e.g., elevated bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, gamma glutamyl transferase)
diagnosis: blood tests (e.g., serum cea, ca19-9, liver function tests)
imaging tests (ultrasound, ct scan, mri, mrcp)
treatments: chemotherapy (e.g., 5-fluorouracil with leucovorin, gemcitabine, cisplatin, irinotecan, capecitabine)
locoregional therapies (transarterial chemoembolization (tace), transarterial radioembolization (tare), ablation therapies)
targeted therapy (erlotinib, infigratinib (truseltiq), pemigatinib (pemazyre), ivodesinib (tibsovo), futibatinib (lytgobi))

diseases.summary: Cholangiocarcinoma, also known as bile duct cancer, is a rare type of cancer that forms in the bile ducts, which are tubes that carry digestive bile from the liver to the small intestine. It can occur inside or outside the liver, with extrahepatic forms being more common. The disease is typically an adenocarcinoma and often presents as incurable at diagnosis, making early detection crucial. It is rare in the Western world but has higher rates in Southeast Asia, often linked to parasitic infections. Symptoms include jaundice, abdominal pain, and weight loss, while diagnosis involves imaging, blood tests, and biopsy. Treatment options include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and targeted therapies.
causes: genetic mutations (e.g., fgfr2 fusion, idh1 mutation)
cellular progression from hyperplasia and metaplasia to dysplasia and carcinoma
risk_factors: infection with liver flukes (opisthorchis viverrini, clonorchis sinensis)
congenital liver malformations (e.g., caroli disease, choledochal cysts)
diagnosis: ultrasound of liver and biliary tree
examination of cells from tumor under microscope

diseases.summary: Bladder cancer is an abnormal growth of cells in the lining of the bladder, a hollow organ in the lower abdomen that stores urine. These cells can form a tumor that may spread and damage the bladder and other organs. It is the sixth most common type of cancer in the United States and the tenth most commonly diagnosed cancer globally.
causes: changes to the dna of bladder cells
occupational exposure to aromatic amines (e.g., benzidine, beta-naphthylamine, ortho-toluidine)
long-term use of pioglitazone (for type 2 diabetes)
risk_factors: exposure to certain chemicals in the workplace
symptoms: blood in urine (haematuria, visible or microscopic)
flank pain (due to kidney swelling from urine blockage)
pain and swelling around lymph nodes (abdomen or groin)
diagnosis: transurethral resection of bladder tumor (turbt) for biopsy
physical examination (digital rectal exam, pelvic exam)
urine tests for bladder tumor antigen (bta)
urine tests for mrna of tumor-associated genes
ct scanning of upper urinary tract
treatments: urinary diversion (e.g., ileal conduit, continent urinary diversion)
intravesical chemotherapy (e.g., mitomycin c, epirubicin, gemcitabine, docetaxel, valrubicin)
systemic chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatin, gemcitabine, methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, carboplatin, vinflunine, paclitaxel, pemetrexed)
immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., pembrolizumab, atezolizumab, nivolumab, avelumab)

diseases.summary: Bone cancer is an abnormal growth of tissue in bone, which can be benign or malignant. Malignant bone tumors can originate in the bone (primary) or spread from other parts of the body (secondary), with secondary tumors being significantly more common. Primary bone cancers include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, and Ewing's sarcoma.
causes: metastasis from other cancers (e.g., lung cancer, breast cancer, thyroid cancer, kidney cancer, prostate cancer)
risk_factors: age (10-19 years for osteosarcoma and ewing's sarcoma)
presence of primary cancer in other organs (e.g., lung, breast, thyroid, kidney, prostate)
symptoms: pain (often worse at night and at rest)
treatments: surgery (e.g., limb amputation, limb sparing surgery, bone graft, artificial bone replacement, limb salvage prostheses, allograft, tumor-devitalized autograft, vascularized fibula graft, distraction osteogenesis, custom-made implants)
subtypes: pleomorphic undifferentiated sarcoma (formerly malignant fibrous histiocytoma)
germ cell tumors (e.g., teratoma, sacrococcygeal teratoma)
other mesenchymal tumors of bone (who 2020 classification)

diseases.summary: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is a chronic blood cancer originating in the bone marrow, characterized by the overproduction of abnormal lymphocytes. These abnormal cells displace healthy blood cells, leading to symptoms such as infection, anemia, and easy bleeding. It primarily affects adults, especially those over 50, and can spread to other body parts.
causes: genetic changes in bone marrow cells
chromosomal translocations (general to hematologic malignancies, arising from aberrant dna double-strand break repair)
risk_factors: family history of cll or other blood and bone marrow diseases
exposure to certain chemicals (e.g., agent orange)
symptoms: pain or feeling of fullness below the ribs
diagnosis: blood chemistry tests (e.g., basic metabolic panel, comprehensive metabolic panel, kidney function tests, liver function tests, electrolyte panel)
flow cytometry tests (on blood, bone marrow, or other tissue)
genetic tests (for gene and chromosome changes)

diseases.summary: A brain tumor is an abnormal growth of cells in the brain tissues, which can be benign (non-cancerous) or malignant (cancerous). They are classified as primary (originating in the brain) or secondary (metastatic, spreading from other parts of the body). Symptoms vary based on tumor size and location, and can include headaches, seizures, and cognitive changes.
causes: ct scan radiation (up to 4% of brain cancers)
ionizing radiation (including radiation treatment for other cancers)
mutations and deletions of tumor suppressor genes (e.g., p53)
symptoms: headaches (often in the morning, worsened by valsalva maneuver, causing awakening from sleep, progressively worsening, subsiding after vomiting, due to raised intracranial pressure)
speech difficulties (e.g., decreased production, difficulty speaking, poor language interpretation)
vision problems (e.g., poor vision, vision loss, visual abnormalities)
cognitive impairment (e.g., problems with thinking, poor reasoning, poor planning, poor memory, difficulty recognizing)
behavioral changes (e.g., inappropriate social behavior, personality changes, temper tantrums, lower inhibition)
cranial nerve palsies (e.g., facial paralysis, abnormal eye movement, swallowing difficulty)
diagnosis: magnetic resonance imaging (mri) (with contrast enhancement, t1, t2, flair imaging)
magnetic resonance angiography (mra) (with or without gadolinium contrast)
perfusion magnetic resonance imaging (pmri) (with gadopentetate dimeglumine contrast)
computed tomography (ct) scan (with iodine-based or barium sulfate contrast)
positron emission tomography (pet) scan (using radiolabelled substances like fdg)
liquid biopsy (experimental, from blood, csf, urine)
treatments: surgery (resection, gross total resection, cytoreduction/debulking, minimally invasive techniques, trans-nasal trans-sphenoidal approach, craniotomy)

radiation therapy (radiotherapy, external beam radiation therapy, whole-brain radiotherapy treatment/wbrt, whole-brain irradiation, radiosurgery, stereotactic radiosurgery, gamma knife, cyberknife, novalis tx radiosurgery, brachytherapy, proton therapy, hypofractionated radiation therapy, postoperative radiotherapy)
chemotherapy (postoperative chemotherapy, chemotherapy agents like temozolomide)
retroviral replicating vectors (experimental, toca 511 & toca fc)

diseases.summary: Breast cancer is a cancer that starts in breast tissue when cells in the breast change and grow out of control, forming a mass called a tumor. It can be 'in situ' (not spread) or 'invasive' (spread to nearby tissues, lymph nodes, or metastasize to other parts of the body). It is the most common invasive cancer in women globally and the second most common type of cancer in women in the United States, though it can also affect men.
causes: interaction of environmental factors and genetic susceptibility
mutations in dna repair genes (e.g., tp53, brca1, brca2)
inherited brca1/brca2 mutations impairing dna repair
estrogen oxidative metabolites causing dna damage
risk_factors: history of benign breast disease (e.g., atypical ductal hyperplasia, fibrocystic changes)
inherited genetic predisposition (e.g., brca1, brca2, palb2, tp53, pten, palb1 mutations)
reproductive history increasing estrogen exposure (early menstruation, late or no first birth, late menopause)
hormone replacement therapy for menopause (especially combined progesterone/estrogen)
radiation exposure to breast/chest (especially before age 30)
circadian disruptions related to shift-work and routine late-night eating
exposure to certain chemicals (pcbs, pahs, organic solvents)
symptoms: new lump or thickening in breast or armpit
change in the size or shape of the breast
dimpling or puckering of breast skin ('orange peel' appearance)
unusual nipple discharge (sudden, bloody, or unilateral)
pain in any area of the breast
substantial breast swelling and redness (inflammatory breast cancer)
shortness of breath (distant spread, lung metastases)
speech, vision, memory, or behavioral disruptions (brain metastases)
diagnosis: breast biopsy (core needle biopsy, fine-needle aspiration)
blood chemistry tests (bmp, cmp, electrolyte panel)
treatments: surgery (mastectomy, lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, breast-conserving surgery, sentinel lymph node biopsy, breast reconstruction)
chemotherapy (e.g., cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, fluorouracil, paclitaxel, cisplatin)
hormone therapy (e.g., tamoxifen, aromatase inhibitors, gnrh-targeted drugs, cdk4/6 inhibitors, mtor inhibitors)
targeted therapy (e.g., her2-targeted antibodies, parp inhibitors, pik3ca inhibitors)
supportive care (e.g., antiemetics, cold caps, antidepressants, physical therapy, cbt, yoga, peer support)

diseases.summary: Carcinoid syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome comprising signs and symptoms that occur secondary to neuroendocrine tumors, most often found in the gut or lungs. It is caused by these tumors releasing biologically active substances, primarily serotonin, into the blood, leading to characteristic symptoms such as flushing, diarrhea, and less frequently, heart failure and bronchoconstriction.
causes: release of biologically active substances (serotonin, histamine, tachykinins, kallikrein, prostaglandins) by neuroendocrine tumors
metastasis of neuroendocrine tumors to the liver (allowing substances to bypass first-pass metabolism)
neuroendocrine tumors arising in the bronchi (allowing products to reach systemic circulation before liver metabolism)
risk_factors: presence of neuroendocrine tumors (occurs in approximately 10% of all, or 3040% of more advanced/well developed nets)
african american ethnicity (appears to be affected more often)
stressful procedures (anesthesia, surgery, radiation treatment) can trigger carcinoid crisis
symptoms: heart disease (cardiac complications, fibrosis of tricuspid and pulmonic valves, heart murmur)
diagnosis: imaging studies of abdomen and pelvis
nuclear medicine gamma camera imaging (using radioactive somatostatin analogues like indium-111 pentetreotide)
echocardiogram (with color doppler for carcinoid heart disease)
treatments: symptomatic control with somatostatin analogues (octreotide, lanreotide, pasireotide)
liver-directed therapies (radiofrequency ablation, radioembolization for liver metastases)
surgical valve repair or replacement (for carcinoid heart disease)

diseases.summary: Carcinoid tumors are rare, slow-growing neuroendocrine cancers primarily originating in the digestive tract or lungs. They are often asymptomatic in early stages, but can produce hormones, notably serotonin, leading to carcinoid syndrome, characterized by flushing, diarrhea, and breathing difficulties. They have malignant potential and can metastasize.

Carcinosarcomas are rare malignant tumors composed of a mixture of carcinoma (epithelial cancer) and sarcoma (mesenchymal/connective tissue cancer), which can develop in diverse organs such as the skin, lungs, uterus, and ovaries.
causes: collision of two independent tumors (collision tumor hypothesis)
pseudosarcomatous reaction to epithelial malignancy (composition hypothesis)
divergent differentiation from a common pluripotential stem cell (combination hypothesis)
metaplastic sarcomatous transformation of the epithelial component (conversion/divergence hypothesis)
early alteration in histogenesis with late transformation or degeneration of the epithelial component
risk_factors: sun-damaged skin (associated with collision tumor hypothesis)

diseases.summary: Castleman disease is a group of rare lymphoproliferative disorders characterized by enlarged lymph nodes and a broad range of inflammatory symptoms and laboratory abnormalities. It involves the overproduction of cytokines and other inflammatory proteins by the body's immune system, and distinct abnormal lymph node features. The disease affects the lymphatic system, which is crucial for fighting infection and maintaining fluid balance.
causes: genetic change in lymph node tissue (unicentric castleman disease)
human herpesvirus 8 (hhv-8) infection (hhv-8-associated multicentric castleman disease)
cancerous cell population in poems syndrome producing cytokines (poems-associated multicentric castleman disease)
symptoms: symptoms due to compression of surrounding structures by enlarged lymph nodes
symptoms related to hiv infection (hhv-8-associated mcd)
diagnosis: microscopic analysis (histology) of enlarged lymph node tissue
characteristic abnormal lymph node features (e.g., plasmacytic, hyaline vascular, hypervascular, mixed features)
staining for latency-associated nuclear antigen (lana-1) to detect hhv-8 infection
international consensus diagnostic criteria for imcd (established in 2017)
evidence-based diagnostic criteria for ucd (established in 2020)
treatments: rituximab (for ucd with compression symptoms, first-line for hhv-8-associated mcd, also used for imcd if siltuximab ineffective)
anti-interleukin-6 (il-6) therapy (for ucd with inflammatory syndrome, first-line for imcd)
treatment directed at poems syndrome (for poems-associated mcd)
cytotoxic chemotherapies (for hhv-8-associated mcd, for critically ill imcd patients)
tocilizumab (if siltuximab not available for imcd)
sirolimus (if siltuximab not effective for imcd)

diseases.summary: Cervical cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the cells of the cervix, the lower, narrow end of the uterus. It typically develops slowly from precancerous changes called cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) over 10 to 20 years, often without early symptoms. Almost all cases are caused by persistent infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV). It is the fourth-most common cancer and cause of cancer death in women globally, with higher incidence and mortality in low- and middle-income countries.
causes: long-lasting infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (hpv)
integration of high-risk hpv dna into host genome
hpv viral proteins e6 and e7 inducing cancer
hpv e6 protein degrading tumor suppressor protein p53
hpv e7 protein degrading and inactivating tumor suppressor protein prb
loss of p53 and prb leading to increased blood vessel growth (vegf over-expression), loss of tumor cell suppression, and cell cycle regulation disruptions
risk_factors: weakened immune system (e.g., due to hiv, immunosuppressant medications)
multiple pregnancies (especially seven or more full-term pregnancies)
starting sex at a young age
having many sexual partners or partners with many sexual partners
symptoms: abnormal vaginal bleeding (after sex, between menstrual periods, after douching, after pelvic exam, heavy bleeding)
vaginal discharge (watery, strong odor, contains blood)
leakage of urine or faeces from the vagina (rare)
hydronephrosis with flank pain (due to blocked ureters)
blood clots in legs (due to blocked pelvic veins)
diagnosis: medical history and family health history review
colposcopy (magnified visual inspection of cervix, often with acetic acid and lugol's iodine staining)
cervical biopsy (tissue sample removal for microscopic examination, e.g., punch biopsy)
loop electrical excision procedure (leep) (for severe precancerous lesions)
cervical conization (cone biopsy) (for severe precancerous lesions or diagnosis)
medical imaging (ultrasound, ct scan, mri) to check for tumor spread or alternative diseases
treatments: surgery (excision, ablation, hysterectomy, radical hysterectomy, trachelectomy, exenteration)
chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatin-based chemotherapy, combination of hycamtin and cisplatin)
immunotherapy (immune checkpoint inhibitors: pembrolizumab (keytruda), cemiplimab-rwlc (libtayo), tisotumab vedotin (tivdak))
hpv vaccination (as a primary prevention measure, also reduces risk of cancerous changes)
related_genes: tp53 (gene for tumor suppressor protein p53)
rb1 (gene for tumor suppressor protein prb)
vegfa (gene for vascular endothelial growth factor, associated with over-expression)

diseases.summary: Chordoma is a rare, slow-growing cancer (neoplasm) that arises from cellular remnants of the notochord in the bones of the skull base and spine. It is classified as a type of bone cancer and sarcoma, often mistakenly referred to as brain, brainstem, or spinal cord tumors due to its location near critical nervous structures.
symptoms: symptoms vary depending on location and size of the cancer

diseases.summary: Choriocarcinoma is a trophoblastic cancer, often originating in the placenta, characterized by early hematogenous spread to the lungs. It represents the malignant end of the spectrum in gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) and can also be classified as a germ cell tumor, potentially arising in the testis or ovary.
symptoms: testicular cancer (as a presentation in males)
diagnosis: histopathological examination (identification of syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts without villi)
treatments: emaco regimen (etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin d, cyclophosphamide, vincristine)

diseases.summary: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is a cancer of the white blood cells, specifically a type of chronic leukemia. It is characterized by the increased and unregulated growth of myeloid cells in the bone marrow and their accumulation in the blood. CML is a clonal bone marrow stem cell disorder associated with a characteristic chromosomal translocation called the Philadelphia chromosome, which creates the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This gene produces an abnormal protein that causes leukemia cells to grow out of control, crowding out healthy blood cells and leading to infection, anemia, and bleeding.
causes: abnormal bcr-abl protein (tyrosine kinase) leading to uncontrolled cell growth
symptoms: pain or fullness below the ribs on the left side
diagnosis: blood chemistry tests (e.g., basic metabolic panel, comprehensive metabolic panel, kidney function tests, liver function tests, electrolyte panel)
genetic tests for gene and chromosome changes
fluorescent in situ hybridization (fish) for bcr-abl1
imaging tests (e.g., mri, ct, ultrasound) for cancer spread
treatments: high-dose chemotherapy with stem cell support

diseases.summary: Clear cell sarcoma is a rare subtype of cancer, specifically a sarcoma, primarily affecting soft tissues and the dermis. It is characterized by the expression of specific fusion genes, most commonly EWSR1-ATF1. Recurrence is common, and metastasis occurs in over 50% of cases, often to bone, lymph nodes, and lungs.
symptoms: commonly found in extremities (knee, feet, ankle)

diseases.summary: Colorectal cancer is a type of cancer that develops in the tissues of the colon or rectum, which are parts of the large intestine. It is characterized by the uncontrolled growth of cells, often originating from benign polyps, which can then invade and spread to other parts of the body.
causes: mutations in the wnt signaling pathway
mutations in axin1, axin2, tcf7l2, nkd1 genes
deactivation of tgf- and dcc proteins
mutations in kras, raf, pi3k genes
mutations in pten tumor suppressor gene
mutations in fam123b, sox9, atm, arid1a genes (non-hypermutated tumors)
mutations in acvr2a, tgfbr2, msh3, msh6, slc9a9, braf genes (hypermutated tumors)
epigenetic alterations (e.g., abnormal dna methylation, altered microrna expression, histone modifications)
epigenetic reductions of dna repair enzyme expression
enrichment of clostridia and other pro-inflammatory taxa
risk_factors: genetic syndromes (e.g., familial adenomatous polyposis (fap), lynch syndrome, gardner syndrome, serrated polyposis syndrome)
inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., chronic ulcerative colitis, crohn disease)
high alcohol consumption (three or more drinks/day)
diet high in red meat, processed meat, saturated fats, sugar
elevated fecal bile acids (e.g., deoxycholic acid, cholic acid, chenodeoxycholic acid)
ashkenazi jewish ethnicity (due to apc gene mutations)
symptoms: change in bowel habits (diarrhea, constipation, narrower stool)
blood in the stool (bright red or very dark)
diagnosis: stool tests (e.g., fecal occult blood testing (fobt), fecal immunochemical test (fit), fit-dna)
medical imaging (e.g., ct scan, pet scan, mri)
treatments: surgery (e.g., endoscopic resection, partial colectomy, proctocolectomy, radiofrequency ablation, cryosurgery, removal of metastases, cytoreductive surgery, intestinal bypass, stent placement)
chemotherapy (e.g., fluorouracil (5-fu), capecitabine, oxaliplatin, irinotecan, uft, capox, folfox, folfoxiri, folfiri regimens)
targeted therapy (e.g., bevacizumab, aflibercept, cetuximab, panitumumab)
immunotherapy (e.g., immune checkpoint inhibitors, pembrolizumab, dostarlimab)
psychosocial interventions (e.g., talk therapy, support groups)

diseases.summary: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) is a class of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, a cancer of the immune system caused by a mutation of T cells. These cancerous T cells initially migrate to the skin, causing various lesions that progress from itchy rashes to plaques and tumors, and can eventually spread to other parts of the body.
diagnosis: point-based algorithm (international society for cutaneous lymphomas, 2005)

diseases.summary: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) is a rare, locally aggressive malignant soft-tissue sarcoma originating in the dermis. It typically presents as a slow-growing, firm skin lesion resembling a bruise or pimple, often on the torso. While metastasis is rare, local recurrence is common if not completely excised.
causes: chromosomal translocation t(17;22) fusing col1a1 and pdgf genes, leading to a self-stimulatory growth signal
risk_factors: exposure to certain chemicals (general for soft tissue sarcomas)
prior radiation therapy (general for soft tissue sarcomas)
certain genetic diseases (general for soft tissue sarcomas)
pregnancy (may accelerate tumor growth due to progesterone receptor expression)
symptoms: minor firm area of skin (1-5 cm in diameter)
lump or swelling in soft tissue
resembles a bruise, birthmark, or pimple
pain (if spread and pressing on nerves/organs)
trouble breathing (if spread and pressing on organs)
diagnosis: magnetic resonance imaging (mri) (for assessing depth of invasion)
immunohistochemical staining (e.g., for cd34, s-100 protein, hormone receptors)
treatments: radiation therapy (rt) (if clear resection margins not achieved or for advanced disease)
chemotherapy (if clear resection margins not achieved or for advanced disease)
imatinib mesylate (tyrosine kinase inhibitor, for unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic dfsp)

diseases.summary: Desmoid tumor, also known as aggressive fibromatosis, is a rare, locally aggressive and invasive type of fibromatosis related to sarcoma. It arises from fibroblasts and does not metastasize, but can cause pain, loss of function, and life-threatening problems by compressing vital organs. Most cases are sporadic, but some are associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). The condition is characterized by a variable and often unpredictable clinical course, with a tendency for recurrence.
risk_factors: history of previous abdominal surgery (for fap patients and general recurrence)
ctnnb1 mutation 45f (associated with high risk of recurrence)
symptoms: compression of vital organs (e.g., intestines, kidneys, lungs, blood vessels, nerves)
treatments: wnt pathway inhibitors (e.g., e7386, tegavivint, ipafricept, investigational)
oral tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib, sorafenib, pazopanib, sunitinib)
subtypes: desmoid tumor of the head and neck
desmoid tumor of the chest wall
desmoid tumor of the pelvic cavity
desmoid tumor of upper extremity and shoulder girdle
desmoid tumor of lower extremity and pelvic girdle

diseases.summary: Embryonal carcinoma is a relatively uncommon type of nonseminomatous germ cell tumour that occurs in the ovaries and testes. It can present as a palpable mass or widespread metastases, and can be pure or a component of mixed germ cell tumors.
diagnosis: gross examination showing pale grey, poorly defined tumour with haemorrhage and necrosis
microscopic features including indistinct cell borders, mitoses, variable architecture (tubulopapillary, glandular, solid, embryoid bodies), nuclear overlap, and necrosis
identification of blue cells attempting to form primitive tubules (in testicle)
differential diagnosis from seminoma, teratocarcinoma, yolk sac tumor, and sertolileydig cell tumor

diseases.summary: Thymus cancer is a rare cancer that originates in the thymus, a small organ located in the upper chest under the breastbone. The thymus plays a crucial role in the immune system by producing a type of white blood cell during childhood. While sometimes asymptomatic, it can cause respiratory and chest symptoms.

Endometrial cancer is the most common type of uterine cancer, originating in the endometrium (lining of the uterus). It is characterized by abnormal cell growth that can invade or spread, often presenting with abnormal vaginal bleeding, particularly after menopause. While the exact cause is unknown, genetic abnormalities and factors altering hormone balance are significant contributors to its development.
causes: mutations in tumor suppressor genes (e.g., p53, pten, spop)
loss of pten function leading to pi3k/akt/mtor pathway up-regulation
mutations in mismatch repair genes (e.g., mlh1, mlh2, msh2, msh6, pms2)
risk_factors: estrogen-only hormone replacement therapy (hrt) after menopause
starting menstruation at an early age
past radiation therapy to the pelvis
higher circulating testosterone levels in women
symptoms: extremely long, heavy, or frequent bleeding episodes (before menopause)
unusual vaginal discharge (thin white or clear in postmenopausal women)
diagnosis: medical history and family health history review
treatments: bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (removal of ovaries and fallopian tubes)
lymphadenectomy (removal of pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes)
subtypes: ovarian endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation

diseases.summary: Primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET) is a rare, malignant (cancerous) neural crest tumor, typically affecting children and young adults under 25 years of age. Characterized by primitive, undifferentiated cells derived from neuroectoderm, it belongs to the Ewing family of tumors and has an overall 5-year survival rate of about 53%.

Ependymoma is a tumor originating from the ependyma, a tissue of the central nervous system that lines the brain's ventricles and the spinal cord's central canal. It is a common type of childhood brain and spinal cord tumor, accounting for up to 10% of pediatric CNS tumors and 5% of adult intracranial gliomas. While typically intracranial in children and spinal in adults, it can rarely occur in the pelvic cavity. Ependymomas can be benign or malignant, with incidence peaking around age 5 and again at age 35.
symptoms: headache (severe, morning, or relieved after vomiting)
vision problems (e.g., visual loss, inability to distinguish colors, seeing lines)
trouble walking (gait change, rotation of feet)
subtypes: embryonal tumor with multilayered rosettes, c19mc-altered
posterior fossa group a ependymoma (molecular subtype)
posterior fossa group b ependymoma (molecular subtype)

diseases.summary: Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma (EHE) is a rare soft tissue sarcoma and vascular cancer, characterized by a distinct genetic alteration, often a fusion gene involving TAZ/WWTR1 and CAMTA1. It is considered intermediate between angiosarcoma and hemangioma, affecting endothelial cells and commonly found in veins of extremities, liver, lungs, bones, and skin. It typically has an indolent course but can present as an aggressive, high-grade tumor.
causes: fusion of taz (wwtr1) and camta1 genes
abnormal taz-camta1 fusion protein variant that is constitutively active
symptoms: spread to other tissues (in aggressive forms)
subtypes: high grade and more aggressive tumor

diseases.summary: Esophageal cancer is a type of cancer originating in the esophagus, the tube connecting the throat to the stomach. It primarily presents as two main subtypes: esophageal squamous-cell carcinoma (ESCC) and esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC). Common symptoms include difficulty swallowing and weight loss. It is a significant global health concern, being the eighth most common cancer worldwide.
causes: consumption of very hot drinks (over 65 c)
poor diet (low fresh foods, high processed/barbecued meats, pickled vegetables)
history of radiation therapy to the chest
head and neck cancer (due to field cancerization)
tylosis with esophageal cancer (rhbdf2 gene mutation)
human papillomavirus (hpv) infection (possible association with escc)
risk_factors: regular consumption of very hot drinks
history of radiation therapy to the chest
symptoms: abdominal swelling (ascites, due to liver metastasis)
excess fluid around lungs (pleural effusion, due to lung metastasis)
treatments: chemotherapy (cisplatin, carboplatin, oxaliplatin, fluorouracil (5-fu), capecitabine, epirubicin, nivolumab, pembrolizumab)
endoscopic therapy (mucosal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, photodynamic therapy, nd-yag laser, argon plasma coagulation)

diseases.summary: Esophageal cancer is a type of cancer that arises from the esophagus, the tube connecting the throat to the stomach. Early stages are often asymptomatic, but advanced disease typically presents with difficulty swallowing and weight loss.
causes: very hot drinks (over 65 c or 149 f)
poor diet (e.g., high in processed/barbecued meats, pickled vegetables; low in fresh foods)
bile reflux (unconjugated bile acids inducing oxidative stress and dna damage)
risk_factors: history of head and neck cancer
history of radiation therapy to the chest
symptoms: abdominal swelling (ascites due to liver metastasis)
impaired breathing (due to pleural effusion from lung metastasis)
treatments: chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatin, carboplatin, oxaliplatin, fluorouracil, capecitabine, epirubicin)
mucosal ablation (e.g., radiofrequency ablation, photodynamic therapy, nd-yag laser, argon plasma coagulation)

diseases.summary: Ewing sarcoma is a rare pediatric cancer that forms in bone or soft tissue, most commonly in the legs, pelvis, and chest wall. It primarily affects children, teenagers, and young adults, with a peak incidence between 10 and 20 years of age. It is the second most common bone cancer in children and adolescents. The disease is often characterized by a genetic translocation, most frequently between chromosomes 11 and 22, leading to an EWS-FLI1 fusion protein. At diagnosis, about 25% of cases have already spread to other parts of the body. Treatment typically involves a multidisciplinary approach including chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgery, with a 5-year survival rate of over 70% for localized disease.
causes: reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11;22)
fusion of ewsr1 gene and fli1 gene
symptoms: pain at the site of the tumor
swelling at the site of the tumor
diagnosis: immunohistochemistry (e.g., cd99 positive, mic2 positive, cd45 negative)
molecular pathology (identifying chromosomal translocations, e.g., t(11;22))
conventional radiographs (showing 'moth eaten' pattern, codman triangle, onion peel appearance)
treatments: chemotherapy (multidrug, e.g., vincristine, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, ifosfamide, etoposide)

diseases.summary: Eye cancer is a rare disease that can affect all parts of the eye. It can be primary, starting within the eye (e.g., intraocular melanoma, lymphoma, retinoblastoma), or metastatic, spreading to the eye from other primary cancers (e.g., breast, lung). Eye cancers can be malignant or benign, with malignant forms often referred to as eye cancer. Treatment varies by type and advancement, including surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy.
causes: metastasis from other primary cancers (e.g., breast cancer, lung cancer, prostate cancer, kidney cancer, thyroid cancer, skin cancer, colon cancer, blood cancer, bone marrow cancer)
risk_factors: presence of a nevus (for melanoma development)
symptoms: dark spot on iris or conjunctiva
whitish or yellowish glow through the pupil (leukocoria)
pressure effects on muscles and optic nerve
diagnosis: evaluation of photographs for abnormal red eye reflex (e.g., white/yellow dot for retinoblastoma)
treatments: exenteration (removal of eye and orbital contents, potentially eyelids)
iridectomy (removal of part of the iris)
iridocyclectomy (removal of iris and ciliary body muscle)
subtypes: uveal melanoma (choroid melanoma, iris melanoma, ciliary body melanoma)
primary intraocular lymphoma (non-hodgkin's, b-cell type, t-cell type)

diseases.summary: Fallopian tube cancer is a malignant neoplasm that originates from the fallopian tube. It is grouped under epithelial ovarian cancers and shares similarities and treatments with ovarian and primary peritoneal cancers. It occurs when there are genetic mutations in the DNA, often of unknown cause, but can also be inherited. The cancer forms in the tissues lining a fallopian tube, which are part of the female reproductive system.
risk_factors: inherited brca1 or brca2 gene mutations
symptoms: pain in the abdomen or pelvis
swelling in the abdomen or pelvis
feeling of pressure in the abdomen or pelvis
sudden or frequent urge to urinate
diagnosis: imaging tests (transvaginal ultrasound, abdominal ultrasound, ct scan, mri)
detection of a pelvic mass on routine gynecologic examination
treatments: surgery (total abdominal hysterectomy, removal of ovaries, tubes, uterus, cervix, omentum removal, lymph node sampling)

diseases.summary: Fibrosarcoma is a malignant mesenchymal tumor derived from fibrous connective tissue, characterized by immature proliferating fibroblasts or undifferentiated anaplastic spindle cells in a storiform pattern. It originates in fibrous tissues of the bone and invades long or flat bones, as well as the periosteum and overlying muscle. It can occur in adults and infants, with infantile fibrosarcoma often being congenital.
causes: translocation between chromosomes 12 and 15 (t(12;15)(p13;q25)) resulting in etv6-ntrk3 fusion gene (in infantile type)
trisomy for chromosomes 8, 11, 17, or 20 (in infantile type)
symptoms: local recurrence (following surgery in dogs and cats)
diagnosis: ihc (vimentin positive, cytokeratin negative, s100 negative, actin variable)

diseases.summary: Gallbladder cancer is a rare cancer that affects the pear-shaped organ under the liver that stores bile. It is more common in women and certain ethnic groups. The cancer is often diagnosed late, making it difficult to treat. It can spread to other organs like the liver, bile duct, stomach, and duodenum.
causes: congenital abnormalities of the bile duct (e.g., choledochal cyst)
diagnosis: incidental finding during cholecystectomy for gallstones

diseases.summary: Gastric cancer is a malignant tumor of the stomach that develops in the lining of the stomach due to abnormal cell growth. Most cases are gastric carcinomas, with subtypes including gastric adenocarcinomas. Lymphomas and mesenchymal tumors can also occur in the stomach. The cancer can spread to other parts of the body, including the liver, lungs, bones, lining of the abdomen, and lymph nodes. It is the fifth-leading type of cancer globally and the third-leading cause of cancer death.
risk_factors: dietary factors (pickled vegetables, fried foods, smoked foods, salt-rich foods, meat, processed meat, red meat)
symptoms: yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes
bloating of the stomach after meals
diagnosis: computed tomography (ct) scanning of the abdomen
blood tests for tumor markers (carcinoembryonic antigen, carbohydrate antigen)
treatments: surgery (gastrectomy, endoscopic mucosal resection, endoscopic submucosal dissection)
chemotherapy (e.g., 5-fluorouracil, cisplatin, epirubicin, etoposide, docetaxel, oxaliplatin, capecitabine, irinotecan)
targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab for her2-overexpressing tumors)
subtypes: extranodal marginal zone b-cell lymphomas (malt type)

diseases.summary: Stomach cancer is a malignant tumor that develops in the lining of the stomach due to abnormal cell growth. It most commonly affects older individuals and can spread to other parts of the body. Early diagnosis is challenging due to non-specific symptoms, often leading to advanced disease at presentation. The prognosis is generally poor, especially for advanced cases.
causes: genetic syndromes (e.g., hereditary diffuse gastric cancer)
risk_factors: salted, smoked, or pickled foods consumption
symptoms: yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes
bloating of the stomach after meals
diagnosis: imaging tests (e.g., ct scan, pet scan, abdominal ultrasound)
tumor markers (e.g., carcinoembryonic antigen, carbohydrate antigen)
treatments: surgery (e.g., gastrectomy, endoscopic mucosal resection, endoscopic submucosal dissection)
chemotherapy (e.g., 5-fluorouracil, cisplatin, epirubicin, etoposide, docetaxel, oxaliplatin, capecitabine, irinotecan)
targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab for her2-overexpressing cancer)
treatment of h. pylori infection (for malt lymphomas)
subtypes: extranodal marginal zone b-cell lymphomas (malt type)

diseases.summary: Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) is a group of pregnancy-related tumors that occur when cells in the womb start to proliferate uncontrollably. These cells, called trophoblasts, normally grow to form the placenta. GTD can be benign or malignant, with hydatidiform mole being the most common type. It can simulate pregnancy and produces chorionic gonadotropin. GTD primarily affects women of child-bearing age but can rarely occur in postmenopausal women.
causes: abnormal conception with excessive placental development
fertilized egg implants into the uterus, but chorionic villi do not develop properly
maternal ovum with no functional dna (complete hydatidiform mole)
dispermic fertilization of an empty ovum (complete hydatidiform mole)
dispermic fertilization of a normal ovum (partial hydatidiform mole)
diagnosis: tests done after miscarriage or abortion
hcg testing (for persistent abnormal vaginal bleeding after pregnancy)
hcg testing (for acute respiratory or neurological symptoms after pregnancy)

diseases.summary: Glioblastoma is the most aggressive and common type of primary brain cancer, originating from astrocytes. It is characterized by rapid growth, infiltrative nature, and a poor prognosis. Diagnosis is typically made through imaging (CT, MRI) and tissue biopsy, often with molecular characterization. Treatment involves a multimodal approach including surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy, with temozolomide being a common chemotherapeutic agent. Despite treatment, recurrence is frequent.
causes: ionizing radiation exposure (including ct scan radiation)
hereditary syndromes (e.g., neurofibromatosis, li-fraumeni syndrome, tuberous sclerosis, turcot syndrome)
infection with oncogenic cmv (potentially necessary for development)
genetic alterations in rtk, pi3k/akt/mtor, p53, and rb pathways
risk_factors: working in petroleum refining or rubber manufacturing
exposure to sv40, hhv-6, and cytomegalovirus (cmv)
diagnosis: mri scan (often appearing as ring-enhancing lesions)
tissue biopsy (stereotactic biopsy or craniotomy with tumor resection)
molecular characterization (e.g., idh1/idh2 mutation status, egfr amplification, tert promoter mutation, atrx expression)
mr spectroscopy (for tumor metabolite concentration, e.g., increased choline peak)
treatments: high-dose steroids (e.g., dexamethasone) for swelling reduction

diseases.summary: A rare neoplasm arising from the glomus body, mainly found under the nail, on the fingertip, or in the foot. The majority are benign but can show malignant features. They are modified smooth muscle cells that control the thermoregulatory function of dermal glomus bodies.
causes: deletions in the glmn (glomulin) gene (familial glomangiomas)
risk_factors: being female (solitary glomus tumors, especially subungual lesions)
younger age (multiple glomus tumors develop earlier)
symptoms: lump in the neck (head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
sore in the mouth or throat (head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
sore throat that does not go away (head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
trouble swallowing (head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
change or hoarseness in the voice (head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
diagnosis: criteria for malignancy: tumor size > 2 cm and subfascial or visceral location, atypical mitotic figures, marked nuclear atypia, any level of mitotic activity
physical exam of the area (head and neck cancer)
blood and/or urine tests (head and neck cancer)
biopsy or cell collection for microscopic examination (head and neck cancer)
treatments: rehabilitation (physical therapy, dietary counseling, speech therapy for head and neck cancer)
subtypes: glomangiosarcomas arising in benign glomus tumors (gabg)

diseases.summary: Granulosa cell tumours are estrogen-secreting tumours that arise from granulosa cells. They are part of the sex cordgonadal stromal tumour group and can occur in both ovaries and testicles. These tumours are considered malignant and are treated similarly to other malignant ovarian tumours. The ovarian disease has adult and juvenile forms, both characterized by indolent growth and high recovery rates, often presenting as stage I.
causes: somatic mutation in the foxl2 gene (c.402c>g, p.c134w) in adult granulosa cell tumours
somatic mutations of akt1 (in-frame duplications in the pleckstrin-homology domain or point mutations) in juvenile granulosa cell tumours
diagnosis: gross appearance (tumour size, oval shape, soft consistency)
histology (reticular, trabecular areas, interstitial haemorrhage, callexner bodies)
histological distinction between adult and juvenile forms (cytoplasm, nuclei, follicle organization)
treatments: treatment as other malignant ovarian tumours
subtypes: juvenile type testicular granulosa cell tumor

diseases.summary: Hairy cell leukemia (HCL) is an uncommon hematological malignancy characterized by the accumulation of abnormal B lymphocytes, often referred to as 'hairy cells' due to their cytoplasmic projections. These abnormal cells accumulate in the bone marrow, interfering with the production of normal blood cells, leading to pancytopenia. HCL typically has an indolent course, but patients frequently relapse. Despite this, with treatment, life expectancy is usually comparable to the general population.
causes: genetic mutations (braf v600e mutation is a driver mutation in nearly all cases)
possible correlation with herbicides (extrapolated from other chronic b-cell leukemias/lymphomas)
risk_factors: older age (median age at diagnosis is 55-60 for classic hcl, over 70 for hcl-v)
male sex (4:1 male to female ratio for classic hcl)
farming and gardening (correlates with increased risk in some studies)
exposure to herbicides (potential risk factor, though not specifically proven for hcl)
symptoms: infections (due to low white blood cell count)
fatigue (due to lack of red blood cells)
easy bleeding (due to low platelet count)
petechiae (tiny red dots under the skin due to bleeding)
diagnosis: complete blood count (cbc) showing low white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets
blood smear examination (presence of hairy cells with characteristic projections)
bone marrow biopsy (confirmation of hcl infiltration and absence of other diseases)
flow cytometry (detection of specific cell surface markers like cd19, cd20, cd22, cd11c, cd25, cd103, fmc7)
annexin a1 and braf v600e mutant protein testing
imaging tests (e.g., ct scans for abdominal lymphadenopathy)
treatments: watchful waiting (for asymptomatic patients with no significant cytopenia or organomegaly)
rituximab (anti-cd20 monoclonal antibody, often combined with purine analogs)
splenectomy (may be used when other therapies fail and spleen has high disease burden)
blood transfusions (for low red blood cells or platelets)
filgrastim (to stimulate white blood cell production, routine use not recommended after cladribine)
moxetumomab pasudotox (anti-cd22 immunotoxin, for relapsed disease)
trametinib (mek inhibitor, in combination with braf inhibitors)
cobimetinib (mek inhibitor, in combination with braf inhibitors)
related_genes: ighv (immunoglobulin gene vh4-34 rearrangement is a poor prognostic factor)

diseases.summary: Head and neck cancer is a general term for cancers that develop in the mouth, nose and sinuses, salivary glands, and throat and voice box (larynx). Most head and neck cancers are squamous cell cancers, which begin in the moist tissues lining the head and neck. The cancer cells may spread into deeper tissue as the cancer grows. Other cancers, such as brain cancer, eye cancer, and esophageal cancer, can occur in the head and neck but are usually not considered head and neck cancers due to different treatments.
causes: exposure to certain toxic substances at work
radiation exposure to the head and neck
genetic variations in alcohol metabolism pathways
risk_factors: history of head or neck cancer
exposure to certain toxic substances at work
radiation exposure to the head and neck
symptoms: sore in the mouth or throat that does not heal
painful sore in the mouth or throat
sore throat that does not go away
change or hoarseness in the voice
ulcer in the mouth that does not heal
red or white patches in the mouth
inflammation of the mouth or throat (mucositis)
visible lumps on the outside of the neck or oral cavity
enlarged lymph node on the outside of the neck
lump in the lip, mouth, or gums
discolored patches that persist in the mouth
food and drink going down the wrong way (aspiration)
long time to chew and swallow food
voice may become hoarse or weak
subtypes: paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer

synonyms: Malignant liver cancer occurring in infants and children
diseases.summary: Hepatoblastoma is a malignant liver cancer occurring in infants and children, composed of tissue resembling fetal liver cells, mature liver cells, or bile duct cells. It is typically unifocal, affects the right lobe of the liver more often than the left lobe, and can metastasize. It is most commonly diagnosed during a child's first three years of life.
causes: constitutive activation of the wnt signaling pathway
symptoms: lump or pain on the right side of the abdomen
asymptomatic at diagnosis (often advanced at diagnosis)

diseases.summary: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common type of primary liver cancer in adults and is a leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide. It most commonly occurs in individuals with chronic liver disease, particularly cirrhosis or fibrosis, often stemming from chronic liver injury and inflammation. HCC is rare in those without chronic liver disease. The incidence is increasing in higher-income countries due to rising rates of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and hepatitis C virus infections. It is more common in males than females.
causes: deficiency in bile salt export pump (abcb11 mutation)
risk_factors: anabolic steroid abuse (associated with benign tumors transforming)
chronic viral hepatitis (estimated cause of 80% cases globally)
symptoms: lump or pain on the right side of the abdomen
symptoms may not be present until cancer is advanced
diagnosis: liver biopsy (historically required, now often not needed if imaging is conclusive)
ultrasound screening (every six months for high-risk individuals)
li-rads classification system for liver lesions
treatments: targeted therapy (e.g., sorafenib, lenvatinib, regorafenib, cabozantinib, ramucirumab)

diseases.summary: Hodgkin lymphoma is a cancer that develops in the lymph system, which is part of the immune system. It starts in different types of white blood cells called lymphocytes. A hallmark of Hodgkin lymphoma is the presence of multinucleated ReedSternberg cells in the lymph nodes.
symptoms: painless, swollen lymph nodes (neck, underarm, groin)
diagnosis: blood tests to rule out other conditions
identification of reedsternberg cells in lymph node biopsies

diseases.summary: Hypopharyngeal cancer is a rare type of head and neck cancer where malignant cells grow in the hypopharynx, the area where the larynx and esophagus meet. It originates in the outer layer (epithelium) of the hypopharynx and progresses by spreading into deeper tissues. Due to its late-stage diagnosis and proximity to lymphatic vessels, it has a high mortality rate.
causes: hpv (risk factor for oropharyngeal cancer, but mentioned in general throat cancer context)
symptoms: sore throat that does not go away
pain or ringing in the ears
swollen lymph nodes in the neck
pain that radiates from the throat to the ears
malnutrition and weight loss (due to refusal to eat)

diseases.summary: Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare and aggressive type of breast cancer where cancer cells block lymph vessels in the skin of the breast, causing the breast to become warm, red, and swollen. It often presents with symptoms resembling skin inflammation, such as redness and swelling, and may not be detected by mammography or ultrasound. IBC is characterized by rapid onset of symptoms and is often diagnosed at a later stage.
causes: cancer cells blocking lymph vessels in the skin of the breast
risk_factors: history of breast cancer or benign breast disease
reproductive history leading to more estrogen exposure (early menstruation, late first birth, late menopause)
radiation therapy to the breast or chest
younger age at diagnosis for african-americans
symptoms: scaly, red, or swollen skin in the nipple area or breast
swelling of lymph nodes (under the arm or in the neck)
unusual warmth of the affected breast
breast size may seem to decrease
diagnosis: staging tests (imaging, sentinel lymph node biopsy)

diseases.summary: Colorectal cancer is the development of cancer from the colon or rectum. It is the consequence of uncontrolled growth of colon cells that can invade or spread to other parts of the body. It typically starts as a benign tumor, often in the form of a polyp, which over time becomes cancerous. Globally, it is the third-most common type of cancer.
causes: genetic mutations in the wnt signaling pathway
overexpression of oncogenes (e.g., kras, raf, pi3k)
inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis and crohn's disease)
abnormal dna methylation of tumor suppressor promoters
mutations in the apc gene (ashkenazi jews)
elevated levels of bile acids (deoxycholic acid, cholic acid, chenodeoxycholic acid)

diseases.summary: Bile duct cancer is a rare cancer that can occur in the parts of the bile ducts that are outside or inside the liver. Cancer of the bile duct outside of the liver is more common. Bile ducts carry bile from the liver and gallbladder to the small intestine to help break down fat and remove toxins and waste.
diagnosis: imaging tests of the liver and bile ducts
subtypes: cancer of the bile duct outside of the liver
cancer of the bile duct inside the liver

synonyms: Invasive carcinoma of no special type
Invasive breast carcinoma of no special type
Invasive ductal carcinoma, not otherwise specified
diseases.summary: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC) is a type of breast cancer that begins in the milk ducts and has spread into surrounding breast tissue. It is the most common type of invasive breast cancer, accounting for a significant majority of diagnoses in women and also occurring in men. It is characterized by cells that have invaded beyond the duct walls but lack specific differentiating features of other invasive breast cancer types, making it a diagnosis of exclusion. The disease can spread to nearby lymph nodes or metastasize to distant parts of the body through the lymphatic system or bloodstream. Prognosis varies based on factors like tumor grade, stage, and receptor status.
causes: genetic changes in brca1 and brca2 genes
risk_factors: history of breast cancer or benign breast disease
inherited risk of breast cancer (e.g., brca1/brca2 gene changes)
reproductive history leading to increased estrogen exposure (early menstruation, late first birth, late menopause)
radiation therapy to the breast or chest
being black (tend to have greater severity and worse survival)
symptoms: new lump or thickening in or near the breast or armpit
change in breast size or shape
dimple or puckering in breast skin (orange peel-like texture)
nipple discharge (sudden, bloody, or from one breast)
scaly, red, or swollen skin in the nipple area or breast
metastatic symptoms depending on affected organ
diagnosis: blood chemistry tests (bmp, cmp, electrolyte panel)
dna analysis (diploid vs. aneuploid, s phase percentage)
microscopic evaluation of carcinomatous cells below basement membrane of lactiferous ducts invading stroma
treatments: targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab for her2-positive tumors)
subtypes: breast carcinoma with osteoclast-like stromal giant cells

diseases.summary: Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a type of cancer that causes lesions (abnormal tissue) to grow in different parts of the body, including the skin, lymph nodes, mucous membranes, and other organs. These lesions are usually red or purple and are made of cancer cells, new blood vessels, and blood cells. KS can occur in multiple places simultaneously and is caused by infection with human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8), also known as Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV), in individuals with weakened immune systems.
causes: human herpesvirus-8 (hhv-8) infection in combination with immune suppression
risk_factors: weakened immune systems due to hiv/aids
weakened immune systems due to immunosuppressive medications after organ transplant
being a young man in africa
sexual transmission of kshv (e.g., deep kissing)
symptoms: red, purple, or brown skin lesions (nodules or blotches)
lesions on legs and feet (ankles, soles)
lesions in the mouth (hard palate, gums)
lesions in the stomach or intestines
painful swelling due to lymph and blood flow blockage
diagnosis: detection of kshv protein lana in tumor cells
treatments: adjusting dose or switching immunosuppressive medications (for iatrogenic ks)
injections of chemotherapy into the lesion
highly active antiretroviral therapy (haart) (for aids-associated ks)

diseases.summary: Kidney cancer is a group of cancers that starts in the kidney. It forms in the lining of tiny tubes inside the kidneys. The incidence of kidney cancer has continued to increase since 1930 and is more commonly found in urban areas. It is the 13th most common form of cancer and responsible for 2% of the world's cancer cases and deaths.
risk_factors: misuse of pain medicines for a long time
symptoms: pain in the side that does not go away
palpable swollen lymph nodes in the neck
milky nipple discharge unrelated to normal breast-feeding (galactorrhea)
disorders of nerves, muscles, blood vessels, and blood clotting mechanisms
diagnosis: medical imaging to characterize kidney masses
treatments: pembrolizumab (adjuvant setting for clear cell rcc)
subtypes: carcinoma of the collecting ducts of bellini
renal cell carcinoma associated with neuroblastoma
mucinous tubular and spindle renal cell carcinoma

diseases.summary: Laryngeal cancer is a type of cancer that develops in any part of the larynx (voice box). It is typically a squamous-cell carcinoma. The prognosis is affected by the location of the tumour, which is divided into three anatomical regions: the glottis, the supraglottis, and the subglottis. Laryngeal cancer can spread by direct extension, metastasis to regional lymph nodes, or via the bloodstream.
causes: combined use of alcohol and tobacco
occupational exposure to certain chemicals in metalworking, petroleum, plastics, and textile industries
infections by some forms of hpv
risk_factors: history of head and neck cancer
chronic exposure to carcinogenic effects of alcohol and tobacco
symptoms: a sore throat that does not go away
feeling that something is stuck in the throat
pain or ringing in the ears
diagnosis: imaging tests (chest x-ray, ct or mri scans)
biopsy (histological proof of cancer type and grade)
examination of the larynx, trachea, and esophagus
palpation of the neck and supraclavicular fossa for cervical adenopathy
examination of the oral cavity and oropharynx
treatments: surgery (partial or full removal of the tumour)

diseases.summary: Head and neck cancer is a term for cancers that develop in the mouth, nose and sinuses, salivary glands, and throat and voice box (larynx). Most head and neck cancers are squamous cell cancers, beginning in the moist tissues lining the head and neck. The cancer cells can spread into deeper tissue as the cancer grows. Other cancers like brain cancer, eye cancer, and esophageal cancer are not typically considered head and neck cancers due to different treatments.
causes: hpv infection (for cancers in the tonsils and base of the tongue)
exposure to wood dusts or certain other toxic substances at work (for upper throat, nose, and sinus cancers)
radiation exposure to the head and neck (for salivary gland cancer)
epstein-barr virus (ebv) infection (for upper throat and salivary gland cancers)
risk_factors: history of head or neck cancer
occupational exposure to wood dusts or certain toxic substances
symptoms: sore in the mouth or throat that does not heal and may be painful
sore throat that does not go away
change or hoarseness in the voice
diagnosis: physical exam of the affected area
biopsy or cell collection for microscopic examination

diseases.summary: Leiomyosarcoma (LMS) is a rare malignant smooth muscle tumor that can originate in various hollow organs made of smooth muscles, most commonly the uterus and abdomen. It is a type of soft-tissue sarcoma, representing 10-20% of new cases, and is more frequently diagnosed in adults. LMS are generally resistant to chemotherapy and radiation, with surgical removal at an early stage being the most effective treatment.

Leukemia is a group of blood cancers that start in the bone marrow and produce large numbers of abnormal blood cells, most often white blood cells. These abnormal cells crowd out healthy blood cells, impairing their function. Leukemia can be classified by the type of blood cell affected (lymphocytes or myeloid cells) and its growth rate (acute or chronic).
causes: changes in the genetic material (dna) in bone marrow cells
exposure to natural and artificial ionizing radiation
exposure to alkylating chemotherapy agents for previous malignancies
use of fertility drugs to induce ovulation
risk_factors: high levels of extremely low frequency (elf) magnetic fields (childhood leukemia, limited evidence)
symptoms: petechiae (tiny red dots under the skin)
diagnosis: blood tests (e.g., complete blood count - cbc)
genetic tests (for gene and chromosome changes)

diseases.summary: Liposarcomas are the most common subtype of soft tissue sarcomas, arising from precursor lipoblasts of adipocytes in adipose tissues. They are classified into five forms: atypical lipomatous tumor/well-differentiated liposarcoma, dedifferentiated liposarcoma, myxoid liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid pleomorphic liposarcoma. While some forms are considered benign or premalignant, all can infiltrate locally, recur after surgery, and metastasize, potentially leading to life-threatening diseases. They are often only marginally responsive to current chemotherapy and radiotherapy regimens.
causes: genetic mutations (e.g., amplification of mdm2 and cdk4 genes in alt/wdl and ddl)
translocations involving fus-ddit3 or ewsr1-ddit3 fusion genes in myxoid liposarcoma
inactivation of rb1 tumor suppressor gene in myxoid pleomorphic liposarcoma
risk_factors: hereditary genetic disorders (li-fraumeni syndrome, muirtorre syndromes) predisposing to various cancers
symptoms: pain (less common, due to organ impingement)
diagnosis: genetic findings (e.g., mdm2 or cdk4 gene overexpression, ssmc or giant marker chromosome detection)
detection of ddit3 gene rearrangements (fus or ewsr1) by in situ hybridization or immunohistochemistry (for myxoid liposarcoma)
absence of fus-ddit3 or ewsr1-ddit3 fusion genes (for myxoid pleomorphic liposarcoma)
treatments: chemotherapy (e.g., doxorubicin, ifosfamide, gemcitabine, docetaxel, eribulin, trabectedin)
targeted therapy (e.g., cdk4 or mdm2 gene inhibitors like abemaciclib, ribociclib, milademetan)

diseases.summary: Liver cancer is cancer that starts in the liver. Primary liver cancer originates in the liver, while metastatic liver cancer begins elsewhere and spreads to the liver. Metastatic liver cancer is more common than primary liver cancer. Globally, liver cancer is the sixth-most frequent cancer and the fourth-leading cause of cancer-related death.
causes: hepatitis d virus (hdv) co-infection with hbv
risk_factors: oral contraceptive pill use (longer than five years)
symptoms: lump or pain on the right side of the abdomen
diagnosis: tumor markers (alpha-fetoprotein (afp), carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (ca 199), carcinoembryonic antigen (cea), cancer antigen 125 (ca125))
liver imaging reporting and data system (li-rads)
treatments: targeted therapy (e.g., sorafenib, atezolizumab, nivolumab, pembrolizumab, regorafenib)
ablation therapy (percutaneous ablation, radio frequency ablation, microwave ablation, ethanol injection, acetic acid injection, cryotherapy)

diseases.summary: Lung cancer is a malignant tumor that originates in the tissues of the lungs, usually in the cells that line the air passages. It is the leading cause of cancer death in both men and women. There are two main types: small cell lung cancer and non-small cell lung cancer. These two types grow differently and are treated differently. Non-small cell lung cancer is the more common type.
causes: genetic damage to the dna of lung cells
radon in the home or workplace
certain imaging tests such as ct scans
genetic mutations that arise by chance
loss of tumor suppressor genes on chromosome 3
risk_factors: exposure to radiation therapy to the breast or chest
radon in the home or workplace
certain imaging tests such as ct scans
unit of exposure to ionizing radiation
indoor air pollution from burning wood, charcoal, or crop residue
high consumption of nitrosamines and nitrites
symptoms: a cough that doesn't go away or gets worse
weight loss for no known reason
swelling in the face and/or veins in the neck
pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen
autoimmune deterioration of cerebellum, limbic system, or brainstem
diagnosis: genetic testing (for small cell lung cancer)
imaging tests (to determine location and extent of tumors)

diseases.summary: Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare cancer that occurs in long-standing cases of primary or secondary lymphedema, typically affecting the extremities. It is believed to arise from endothelial cells and may be more accurately referred to as angiosarcoma. It metastasizes quickly.
causes: lymphedema (swelling due to lymphatic system obstruction)
risk_factors: survival of five or more years post-mastectomy
symptoms: tender skin nodule in the extremity
extensive necrotic focus involving skin and subcutaneous tissue

diseases.summary: Lymphoma is a cancer of the lymph system, a part of the immune system. It develops from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell. There are many types, broadly categorized into Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphomas. Non-Hodgkin lymphomas arise when T cells or B cells become abnormal and divide uncontrollably, potentially spreading throughout the body. Lymphomas are a part of the broader group of tumors of hematopoietic and lymphoid tissues.
causes: abnormal t cell or b cell development (for non-hodgkin lymphoma)
epsteinbarr virus infection (for hodgkin lymphoma and some non-hodgkin lymphomas)
human t-lymphotropic virus infection (for some non-hodgkin lymphomas)
symptoms: feeling of fullness in the abdomen
diagnosis: biopsy (lymph node biopsy, bone marrow testing)
imaging (ct scan, pet scan, mri, ultrasound)
treatments: therapy to remove proteins from the blood (plasmapheresis)
watchful waiting (watch and wait, watch and worry)
high-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation
chimeric antigen receptor t cell therapies (e.g., lisocabtagene maraleucel, axicabtagene ciloleucel, tisagenlecleucel, brexucabtagene autoleucel)
subtypes: diffuse large b-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified
diffuse large b-cell lymphoma associated with chronic inflammation
peripheral t-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified
systemic t cell lymphoma of childhood

diseases.summary: Male breast cancer (MBC) is a cancer that originates in the breasts of males. It is much less common than breast cancer in females, accounting for less than 1% of new breast cancer cases worldwide. While many treatment strategies are adopted from female breast cancer, MBC can have distinct presentations, associations, and genetic factors.
causes: genetic mutations (brca1, brca2, chek2, palb2, pten, atm, rad51l3)
tumor protein p53 gene mutations (associated with li-fraumeni syndrome)
dna mismatch repair gene mutations (mlh1, msh2, msh6, pms2, epcam) (associated with lynch syndrome)
pten gene mutations (associated with cowden syndrome)
risk_factors: consumption of hormonal drugs for gender reassignment therapy
occupations with long-term exposure to high temperatures, petrol emissions, or exhaust emissions
gynecomastia (historically considered, but not definitively established as a risk factor)
diagnosis: physical examination (checking for lumps, lymph node enlargement)
needle biopsy (fine-needle aspiration or core needle biopsy)
subtypes: papillary carcinomas of the breast (in situ, encapsulated, solid-papillary, invasive)

diseases.summary: Malignant melanoma of the eye is a type of cancer that affects the eye. It can occur in the outer parts of the eye or inside the eyeball. The most common intraocular cancers in adults are melanoma and lymphoma. Retinoblastoma is the most common eye cancer in children. Cancer can also spread to the eye from other parts of the body.

Malignant mesothelioma is a rare but serious cancer of the mesothelium, the tissue lining the lungs, stomach, heart, and other organs. It most commonly starts in the lungs but can also affect the abdomen or other organs. The disease is strongly linked to asbestos exposure, with a long latency period between exposure and diagnosis.
causes: irradiation of the chest or abdomen
risk_factors: occupational exposure to asbestos (mining, production, working with asbestos products)
