living near naturally occurring asbestos deposits
exposure to talc mines or mills
renovation or diy activities in buildings with asbestos-containing materials
germline mutation in the bap1 gene
symptoms: pain, swelling, or lumps in the abdomen
weight loss for no known reason
ascites (fluid buildup in the abdominal cavity)
pain, trouble swallowing, or swelling of the neck or face (if spread beyond mesothelium)
cardiac symptoms (constrictive pericarditis, heart failure, pulmonary embolism, cardiac tamponade)
orthopnea (shortness of breath when lying flat)
diagnosis: imaging tests (chest x-ray, ct scan, mri)
cytopathology (examination of fluid produced by cancer)
thoracentesis or tube thoracostomy (for pleural fluid)
treatments: chemotherapy (cisplatin, pemetrexed, raltitrexed, gemcitabine, vinorelbine, carboplatin)

diseases.summary: A cancer found in the uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes, and other body parts, characterized by the presence of both carcinomatous (epithelial) and sarcomatous (connective) tissue components. It is divided into homologous and heterologous types based on the origin of the sarcomatous component.
diagnosis: histology (adenocarcinoma mixed with malignant mesenchymal elements)
gross appearance (fleshy, bulky, polypoid, protruding through cervical os)

diseases.summary: A malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST) is a rare and aggressive form of cancer that arises from the connective tissue surrounding peripheral nerves. It is classified as a sarcoma and can occur anywhere in the body where peripheral nerves are present. MPNSTs can be life-threatening, especially if they grow large or metastasize.
causes: mutation of the p53 tumor suppressor gene
symptoms: difficulty in moving the extremity with the tumor
soreness localized to the area of the tumor or extremity
pain or discomfort (numbness, burning, pins and needles)
loss of hearing on one side
numbness or paralysis of the face
subtypes: malignant triton tumors (mpnst with rhabdomyoblastomatous component)

diseases.summary: Malignant Rhabdoid Tumor (MRT) is a rare and aggressive type of cancer that typically affects infants and young children. It is characterized by the presence of large, atypical cells with rhabdoid features. MRT can occur in various parts of the body, most commonly in the kidney (nephroblastoma), brain (medulloblastoma), and soft tissues. The exact cause is not fully understood, but genetic mutations, particularly in the SMARCB1 gene, are strongly associated with its development. Due to its aggressive nature, MRT often has a poor prognosis, and treatment usually involves a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.
causes: genetic mutations in the smarcb1 gene
subtypes: malignant rhabdoid tumor of the kidney
malignant rhabdoid tumor of the brain
malignant rhabdoid tumor of the soft tissues

diseases.summary: Mediastinal germ cell tumors are tumors that derive from germ cell rest remnants in the mediastinum. While germ cell tumors most commonly occur in the gonad, they can occasionally arise elsewhere. Malignant mediastinal tumors are usually symptomatic at the time of diagnosis and can cause symptoms by compressing or invading adjacent structures. Rare cases of adult onset acute megakaryoblastic leukemia are associated with malignant mediastinal germ cell tumor, with similar genetic aberrations found in both malignancies.
causes: abnormal migration of germ cells during embryogenesis
widespread distribution of germ cells to multiple sites during normal embryogenesis
symptoms: compression or invasion of adjacent structures (lungs, pleura, pericardium, chest wall)
minimal symptomatology despite large tumor size (seminomas)
diagnosis: ct of the chest and abdomen
determination of serum levels of hcg
determination of serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein
treatments: chemotherapy using bleomycin, etoposide and cisplatin (for seminomas)
thoracotomy and attempted complete resection (for small, resectable tumors)
surgical resection of any residual disease (for nonseminomatous tumors)
chemotherapy following guidelines for poor-prognosis testicular cancer (for nonseminomatous tumors)
related_genes: inversions in the long arm of chromosome 12

synonyms: Thyroid carcinoma originating from parafollicular cells
diseases.summary: Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) is a form of thyroid cancer that originates from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland, which produce the hormone calcitonin. It is the third most common type of thyroid cancer, accounting for about 3% of all cases. MTC can occur sporadically or be hereditary, often associated with genetic mutations in the RET proto-oncogene.
causes: mutation in the ret proto-oncogene (sporadic and hereditary)
hereditary genetic disorder (familial medullary thyroid cancer)
multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (men2a and men2b)
risk_factors: exposure to certain types of radiation (head or neck radiation treatment as a child, radiation emergency)
certain genetic conditions (e.g., multiple endocrine neoplasia)
family history of thyroid cancer or thyroid disease
symptoms: hoarseness or other changes to voice
diagnosis: physical exam (checking neck for swelling, lumps)
microscopic examination of biopsy (amyloid stroma, hyperplasia of parafollicular cells)
treatments: surgery (total thyroidectomy with bilateral neck dissection)
targeted therapy (protein kinase inhibitors like vandetanib, cabozantinib)
subtypes: medullary thyroid cancer associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2a (men2a)
medullary thyroid cancer associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2b (men2b)

diseases.summary: Medulloblastoma is a common type of primary malignant brain cancer in children that originates in the cerebellum or posterior fossa. It is an invasive, rapidly growing tumor that can spread through cerebrospinal fluid and metastasize to other parts of the brain and spinal cord. Historically classified as a PNET, it is now recognized as distinct from supratentorial PNETs.
diagnosis: t1- and t2-weighted mri with heterogeneous enhancement
treatments: maximal surgical removal of the tumor

diseases.summary: Melanoma is a serious type of skin cancer that develops from melanocytes. It typically occurs on the skin but can rarely affect the mouth, intestines, or eyes. Early signs often involve changes in a mole's size, shape, color, or feel, with a common mnemonic being ABCDE (Asymmetry, Border, Color, Diameter, Evolving).
causes: dna damage from uv light exposure
mutations in ras genes (nras, hras, kras)
loss-of-function mutations in tumor suppressor genes (nf1, tp53, cdkn2a)
kinase fusions (braf, raf1, alk, ret, ros1, ntrk1, ntrk3, met)
risk_factors: ultraviolet light (uv) exposure (sun or tanning devices)
low levels of skin pigment melanin
dysplastic nevus syndrome (familial atypical multiple mole melanoma - fammm)
multiple atypical nevi or dysplastic nevi
occupational exposure to uv radiation (e.g., working in airplanes)
symptoms: change in size, shape, color, or feel of a mole
black or black-blue area in a mole
ragged, blurred, or irregular border of a mole
uneven color of a mole (shades of black, brown, tan)
new lump on the skin (nodular melanoma)
elevated above the skin surface (nodular melanoma)
diagnosis: imaging (ct scans, mris, pet/cts, ultrasound) for metastasis
ldh levels (may be elevated in metastatic melanoma)
treatments: surgery (excision, wide local excision, mohs surgery)
targeted therapy (braf inhibitors, mek inhibitors, c-kit inhibitors, nras inhibitors)
immunotherapy (cytokines like ifn-a and il-2, immune checkpoint inhibitors like ipilimumab, nivolumab, pembrolizumab, anti-pd-1 antibodies, anti-ctla-4 antibodies)
adoptive cell transfer (act) using tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (tils)
adoptive transfer of genetically altered autologous lymphocytes
observation (for early stage or after resection)
subtypes: melanoma with features of a spitz nevus

diseases.summary: Meningioma is a typically slow-growing tumor that forms from the meninges, the membranous layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms depend on the location and occur as a result of the tumor pressing on nearby tissue. Many cases never produce symptoms. They are usually benign but can be atypical or malignant. Meningiomas are extra-axial and vascularized.
risk_factors: unit of exposure to ionizing radiation
symptoms: changes in ability to talk, hear, or see
treatments: radiation therapy (photon-beam, proton-beam, fractionated external beam)

synonyms: Primary neuroendocrine carcinoma of the skin
Primary small cell carcinoma of the skin
diseases.summary: Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) is a rare and aggressive type of skin cancer that typically arises on sun-exposed areas of the body. It is characterized by firm, flesh-colored, red, or blue tumors that can enlarge rapidly. MCC can spread to lymph nodes and other organs. Its development is linked to the Merkel cell polyomavirus (MCPyV), weakened immune systems, and ultraviolet radiation exposure.
risk_factors: immunosuppression (e.g., hiv infection, organ transplant recipients, certain malignancies)
prior skin cancers (e.g., multiple myeloma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, malignant melanoma)
symptoms: firm nodule or mass (0.5 cm to >5 cm diameter)
tumors on head, neck, extremities, perianal region, or eyelid
diagnosis: clinical examination of skin and lymph nodes
light microscopy (basaloid tumor nests with neuroendocrine features)
immunohistochemistry (ihc) for neuroendocrine markers (synaptophysin, chromogranin a) and other markers (pax5, cytokeratin 20)
imaging (pet scan, ct scan) for staging
treatments: immunotherapy (pd-1/pdl1 inhibitors like avelumab, pembrolizumab, nivolumab, ipilimumab)

diseases.summary: Mesothelioma is a rare but serious cancer of the mesothelium, the tissue lining internal organs such as the lungs, heart, and abdomen. It most commonly starts in the lungs and is strongly linked to asbestos exposure, with a long latency period between exposure and disease onset. Symptoms can include breathing difficulties, cough, chest or abdominal pain, and weight loss. Diagnosis often involves imaging tests and biopsy, and treatment options include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, immunotherapy, and targeted therapy.
causes: irradiation of the chest or abdomen
risk_factors: living near asbestos mines or factories
renovation or diy activities in buildings with asbestos
symptoms: swelling of the neck or face
diagnosis: imaging tests (chest x-ray, ct scan, mri)
treatments: chemotherapy (cisplatin, pemetrexed, raltitrexed, gemcitabine, vinorelbine, carboplatin, adriamycin)
multimodality therapy (combination of surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy)

diseases.summary: A malignant mucinous neoplasm, also called mucinous carcinoma, is an abnormal and excessive growth of tissue that produces mucin. It arises from epithelial cells that line certain internal organs and skin.
symptoms: round, elevated, reddish, and sometimes ulcerated mass (when found in skin)
usually located on the head and neck (when found in skin)

diseases.summary: Mucinous tumors are a type of ovarian tumor, accounting for approximately 36% of all ovarian neoplasms. They are characterized by being filled with a mucus-like material produced by mucus-secreting goblet cells. Approximately 75% are benign, 10% are borderline, and 15% are malignant. They can become very large and may present bilaterally, though this is rare for primary tumors.
causes: malignancy may be focally present in mucinous neoplasms of the ovary
risk_factors: smoking (current smokers: relative risk 2.22, past smokers: relative risk 2.02)
symptoms: papillae and solid areas (in borderline and malignant tumors)
diagnosis: differentiation of borderline tumors from malignant tumors based on clear stromal invasion
assessment for cellular atypia and stratification
evaluation of loss of normal tissue architecture
imaging (implied for assessing organ involvement and bilaterality)

diseases.summary: Mucosal melanoma is a rare type of melanoma that affects the mucous membranes, typically occurring in the head and neck, anorectal, vulvovaginal regions, and urinary tract. It is associated with a worse prognosis compared to skin melanomas.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) encompasses several distinct syndromes characterized by tumors of endocrine glands, each with its own pattern. Tumors can be malignant or benign. Benign or malignant tumors of nonendocrine tissues can also occur. MEN syndromes are inherited as autosomal dominant disorders.
symptoms: endocrinopathy of two characteristic affected organs
endocrinopathy of one characteristic organ plus a first-degree relative affected by men syndrome
diagnosis: genetic testing for men1 gene mutations
genetic testing for ret oncogene mutations
clinical evaluation for endocrinopathy of characteristic organs

diseases.summary: Multiple myeloma is a cancer that begins in plasma cells, a type of white blood cell that normally produces antibodies. These cells are part of the immune system. In time, myeloma cells collect in the bone marrow and in the solid parts of bones. As it progresses, bone pain, anemia, renal insufficiency, and infections may occur. Complications may include hypercalcemia and amyloidosis.
causes: chromosomal translocations (e.g., between immunoglobulin heavy chain gene and oncogenes)
risk_factors: occupational exposure to aromatic hydrocarbon solvents (e.g., benzene, toluene, xylene)
certain occupations (firefighting, hairdressing, agricultural and industrial work)
immunodeficiency (due to hiv/aids, organ transplantation, rheumatoid arthritis)
symptoms: bone pain (often in the back or ribs)
neurological symptoms (weakness, confusion, headache, visual changes, retinopathy, radicular pain, loss of bowel or bladder control, carpal tunnel syndrome, peripheral neuropathy)
mouth symptoms (pain, numbness, swelling, jaw expansion, tooth mobility, radiolucency)
rouleaux formation of red blood cells
diagnosis: blood tests (e.g., protein electrophoresis, serum free light chain assay)
urine tests (e.g., protein electrophoresis for bence jones protein)
medical imaging (skeletal survey, mri, ct scan)
histopathology (bone marrow biopsy, immunohistochemistry, flow cytometry)
crab criteria (calcium, renal insufficiency, anemia, bone lesions)
treatments: monoclonal antibodies (e.g., daratumumab, isatuximab, elotuzumab, belantamab mafodotin)
selective inhibitor of nuclear export (e.g., selinexor)
supportive care (e.g., red blood cell transfusions, erythropoietin)

diseases.summary: Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a group of cancers in which blood cells in the bone marrow do not mature properly and therefore do not develop into healthy blood cells. Early on, no symptoms are typically seen. Later, symptoms may include fatigue, shortness of breath, bleeding disorders, anemia, or frequent infections. Some types may develop into acute myeloid leukemia.
causes: unit of exposure to ionizing radiation
exposure to certain chemicals (e.g., benzene, tobacco smoke, pesticides)
exposure to heavy metals (e.g., mercury, lead)
risk_factors: exposure to certain chemicals (e.g., tobacco smoke, pesticides, benzene)
exposure to heavy metals (e.g., mercury, lead)
acquired aplastic anemia following immunosuppressive treatment
symptoms: skin that is paler than usual
pinpoint spots under the skin caused by bleeding (petechiae)
anemia (low rbc count or reduced hemoglobin)
diagnosis: blood tests to eliminate other causes of cytopenias
interphase fluorescence in situ hybridization (fish) testing
morphology and special stains (pas, perls' prussian blue iron stain)
treatments: blood or bone marrow stem cell transplants (hematopoietic stem cell transplantation)
iron chelation therapy (e.g., deferoxamine, deferasirox, deferiprone)
subtypes: myeloid neoplasms with germ line predisposition and organ dysfunction
refractory anemia with excess blasts (raeb-i, raeb-ii)

diseases.summary: Myelofibrosis is a rare bone marrow blood cancer classified as a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It involves the remodeling of bone marrow with osteosclerosis and the secretion of collagen and reticulin proteins (fibrosis), which compromise normal bone marrow function and lead to decreased production of blood cells like erythrocytes, granulocytes, and platelets. It can also be a complication of other myeloproliferative disorders like polycythemia vera and essential thrombocythemia.
causes: somatic mutation in jak2, calr, or mpl genes
risk_factors: previous myeloproliferative disorders (polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia)
symptoms: cachexia (loss of appetite, weight loss, fatigue)
leukoerythroblastic smear (tear-drop rbcs, nucleated rbcs, immature granulocytes)
diagnosis: physical exam of the abdomen (for enlarged spleen or liver)

diseases.summary: Myxofibrosarcoma (MFS) is a rare soft tissue sarcoma, often developing in elderly individuals. It is characterized by its tendency to recur locally after surgical resection, with recurrences often progressing to higher grades, metastasizing, and becoming life-threatening. An epithelioid variant is particularly aggressive.
causes: complex chromosome and/or gene abnormalities including ring chromosomes, double minutes, deletions, and translocations
symptoms: painless, slowly enlarging masses in muscle, skin, or non-cutaneous areas
tumor located in extremity, trunk, or head and neck areas
metastasis to lungs, bone, and lymph nodes
diagnosis: presence of pseudo-lipoblasts in a myxoid sarcoma-like background
magnetic resonance imaging (mri) with t2-weighted imaging showing a tail sign
treatments: radical surgical resection with a 2 cm margin

diseases.disease_name: nasal cavity and paranasal sinus cancer
diseases.summary: Cancer of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses is a rare condition affecting the small hollow spaces around the nose and the passageway behind the nose. These areas are lined with mucus-producing cells. Air passes through the nasal cavity on its way to the throat.

synonyms: Cancer of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses
diseases.summary: Cancer of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses is rare. The paranasal sinuses are small hollow spaces around the nose lined with mucus-producing cells. The nasal cavity is the passageway behind the nose for air to reach the throat.
diagnosis: lighted tube-like instruments that look inside the nose

diseases.summary: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is a type of head and neck cancer originating in the nasopharynx. It is characterized by its distinct occurrence, causes, clinical behavior, and treatment compared to other head and neck cancers. NPC is significantly more common in certain regions of East Asia and Africa and is more prevalent in males. It is a squamous cell carcinoma of an undifferentiated type.
causes: consumption of preserved meats and salted fish containing carcinogenic volatile nitrosamines
human papillomavirus (hpv) (for who type i npc)
risk_factors: living in crowded and less hygienic conditions (for ebv transmission)
symptoms: lump or mass on the back of the neck (often not tender or painful)
swollen lymph nodes in the neck
sore throat that does not go away
nasal regurgitation due to paresis of the soft palate
diagnosis: staging based on clinical and radiologic examination
treatments: radiation therapy (including 3d conformal radiation therapy, intensity-modulated radiation therapy, particle beam therapy, brachytherapy)
immunotherapy (e.g., toripalimab-tpzi with cisplatin and gemcitabine)

diseases.summary: Wilms tumor is a rare type of kidney cancer that typically occurs in children, but can also affect adults. It causes a tumor on one or both kidneys and is highly responsive to treatment, with a high cure rate. It can be associated with certain genetic conditions and birth defects.
causes: alterations to genes such as wt1
alterations to genes such as wt2
nephrogenic rests (fragments of tissue that develop before birth and become cancerous after birth)
acquired somatic mutations in ctnnb1 gene
deletions in the p13 band on chromosome 11

diseases.summary: Neuroblastoma is a type of cancer that forms in nerve cells called neuroblasts. It usually begins in the adrenal glands but can also start in the neck, chest, or spinal cord. Neuroblasts are immature nerve tissue that normally develop into working nerve cells, but in neuroblastoma, they form a tumor. It is the most common cancer in babies and the third-most common cancer in children.
causes: changes in genes (gene variants or mutations)
duplicated segments of the lmo1 gene
copy-number variation within the nbpf10 gene
risk_factors: parental factors around conception and during gestation (occupation, smoking, alcohol consumption, medicinal drug use, birth factors)
exposure to infection early in life
use of hormones and fertility drugs
symptoms: lump in the abdomen, neck, or chest
painless, bluish lumps under the skin
inability to stand, crawl, or walk
distinct bruising and swelling around the eyes
diagnosis: imaging tests (x-rays, ct scan, ultrasound, mri, mibg scan)
microscopy (small, round, blue cells, homer wright pseudorosettes)
international neuroblastoma risk group staging system
treatments: high-dose chemotherapy and radiation therapy with stem cell rescue

diseases.summary: Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) are neoplasms that arise from cells of the endocrine (hormonal) and nervous systems. They most commonly occur in the intestine, pancreas, or lungs. NETs can be slow-growing or aggressive and may produce hormones that cause various syndromes. Diagnosis involves imaging, blood markers, and histopathology. Treatment depends on the tumor's characteristics and may include surgery, somatostatin analogs, chemotherapy, or radionuclide therapy.
risk_factors: inherited familial syndromes (men1, men2, vhl disease, neurofibromatosis type 1, tuberous sclerosis, carney complex)
diagnosis: measurement of corresponding hormones in blood or urine
treatments: chemotherapy (cisplatin with etoposide, doxorubicin with streptozocin, fluorouracil)
subtypes: well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors (low grade, uncertain behavior)
poorly differentiated neuroendocrine carcinomas (large cell, small cell)
mixed tumors (neuroendocrine and epithelial carcinoma features)
large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung (lcnec)
extrapulmonary small cell carcinomas (escc or epscc)
merkel cell carcinoma of anal skin
neuroendocrine tumor of the anterior pituitary
urinary tract carcinoid tumor and neuroendocrine carcinoma

diseases.summary: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) is a group of blood cancers that originate from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell. These abnormal cells can proliferate and spread throughout the body. The disease is categorized into over 60 specific types, grouped by aggressiveness.
causes: abnormal t cells or b cells
exposure to certain chemicals (e.g., polychlorinated biphenyls, dioxins, phenoxy herbicides)
genetic diseases (e.g., klinefelter syndrome, chdiakhigashi syndrome, ataxiatelangiectasia syndrome)
symptoms: feeling of fullness in the abdomen

diseases.summary: Skin cancers are cancers that arise from the skin, occurring when skin cells grow uncontrollably and form malignant tumors. They are the most commonly diagnosed form of cancer in humans, with the primary cause being prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.
causes: prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (uv) radiation from the sun or tanning devices
uvb radiation via direct dna damage (for bcc and scc)
uva radiation via indirect dna damage (for melanoma)
genetic syndromes (e.g., congenital melanocytic nevi syndrome)
use of immunosuppressive medications (e.g., cyclosporin a, azathioprine)
deliberate exposure of sensitive skin to sunlight
risk_factors: childhood exposure to uv radiation (for melanomas and basal-cell cancers)
total uv exposure (for squamous-cell skin cancers)
having moles (20-30% of melanomas develop from moles)
poor immune function (e.g., from medications or hiv/aids)
symptoms: abnormal cells that invade or spread to other parts of the body
changes in the skin that do not heal
changes in existing moles (size, shape, color, irregular edges, more than one color, itchy, bleeds)
painful lesion that itches or burns
large brownish spot with darker speckles
raised, smooth, pearly bump on sun-exposed skin (bcc)
small blood vessels visible within the tumor (bcc)
crusting and bleeding in the center of the tumor (bcc)
red, scaling, thickened patch on sun-exposed skin (scc)
firm hard nodules with a scaly top (scc)
various colors from shades of brown to black (melanoma)
pink, red, or fleshy color (amelanotic melanoma)
change in the size, shape, color, or elevation of a mole (melanoma)
appearance of a new mole during adulthood (melanoma)
pain, itching, ulceration, redness around the site, or bleeding at the site (melanoma)
rapidly growing, non-tender red, purple, or skin-colored bumps (merkel cell carcinomas)
bumps that are not painful or itchy (merkel cell carcinomas)
treatments: biologic immunotherapy agents (e.g., ipilimumab, pembrolizumab, nivolumab, cemiplimab)
topical application of t4n5 liposome lotion (for xeroderma pigmentosum)

diseases.summary: Oligodendrogliomas are a type of glioma believed to originate from oligodendrocytes or glial precursor cells. They primarily occur in adults but are also found in children, comprising about 5% of all central nervous system tumors. They are characterized by a high rate of recurrence and a tendency to increase in grade over time.
causes: irradiation of pituitary adenoma (single case report)
symptoms: headaches associated with increased intracranial pressure
neurological deficits (e.g., visual loss, motor weakness, cognitive decline)
treatments: symptomatic treatment (anticonvulsants for seizures, steroids for brain swelling)

diseases.summary: Oral cancer is a type of head and neck cancer that affects the lining of the lips, mouth, or upper throat. It most commonly begins as a painless red or white patch that thickens, ulcerates, and grows. On the lips, it may appear as a persistent, crusting ulcer that does not heal. Oral cancer can spread into deeper tissues as it grows.
risk_factors: history of head or neck cancer
symptoms: white or red patch in the mouth
lip or mouth sore that won't heal
bleeding, pain, or numbness in the lip or mouth
loose teeth or dentures that no longer fit well
sore throat or feeling that something is caught in the throat
persistent rough patch with ulceration and raised border
crusting and dry ulcer on the lip
numbness in the mouth or lips
numbness in the lip and chin
diagnosis: physical exam of the lips and mouth
biopsy or other procedure to collect cells for microscopic examination
imaging tests (ct scan, mri, pet scan)

diseases.summary: Oropharyngeal cancer is a type of head and neck cancer that affects the oropharynx, including the base of the tongue, tonsils, soft palate, and pharyngeal walls. It is characterized by the abnormal growth of cells that can spread locally and to other parts of the body. The disease is classified into HPV-positive and HPV-negative subtypes, with different risk factors and prognoses.
risk_factors: performing open-mouthed kissing or oral/mouth-genital sex on a person with hpv
diet low in fruit and vegetables
symptoms: sore throat that does not go away
pain or ringing in the ears
lump in the back of the throat or mouth
diagnosis: staging according to cell appearance, dimensions, and extent

diseases.summary: Osteosarcoma is a malignant neoplasm that arises from primitive transformed cells of mesenchymal origin and exhibits osteoblastic differentiation, producing malignant osteoid. It is the most common histological form of primary bone sarcoma and is most prevalent in teenagers and young adults. It can also occur in other animals, including dogs, cats, and dinosaurs.
causes: deletion of chromosome 13q14 inactivating the retinoblastoma gene
risk_factors: bone dysplasias (paget's disease of bone, fibrous dysplasia, enchondromatosis, hereditary multiple exostoses)
middle-aged large and giant breed dogs
infestation with the parasite spirocerca lupi (in dogs)
symptoms: pain (often worse at night, intermittent, varying intensity, long-standing)
pain in the lower femur or below the knee (in active teenagers)
diagnosis: ct scan (bony anatomy, cortex integrity, pathologic fracture, ossification, calcification)
biopsy (orthopedic oncologist for non-facial, oral & maxillofacial surgeon for facial)

diseases.summary: Ovarian cancer is a cancerous tumor that forms in the tissues of an ovary. It can originate from the ovary itself or from nearby structures like the fallopian tubes or the lining of the abdomen. The most common type is epithelial ovarian cancer, which begins in the cells covering the ovary. Other rarer types include malignant germ cell tumors and stromal tumors. Ovarian cancer often lacks early symptoms, and by the time symptoms appear, the cancer is frequently advanced.
risk_factors: inherited brca1 or brca2 gene mutations
symptoms: pain, swelling, or pressure in the abdomen or pelvis
sudden or frequent urge to urinate
pain or bleeding during or after sexual intercourse
diagnosis: blood tests (ca-125, he4, alpha-fetoprotein, hcg, inhibin a/b, lactate dehydrogenase)
exploration of the abdominal cavity during surgery
treatments: bone marrow or stem cell transplant (not explicitly mentioned for ovarian cancer, but a general cancer treatment)
risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy (preventive surgery for high-risk individuals)

synonyms: Malignant germ cell tumors of ovary
diseases.summary: Ovarian germ cell tumors (OGCTs) are a heterogeneous group of tumors derived from primitive germ cells of the embryonic gonad, accounting for about 2.6% of all ovarian malignancies. They are relatively difficult to detect and diagnose at an early stage due to nonspecific symptoms and histological characteristics. Common symptoms include bloating, abdominal distention, ascites, and dyspareunia. The exact cause is unknown, but genetic mutations and environmental factors are implicated. Treatment typically involves surgical resection coupled with chemotherapy.
causes: formation of malignant cancer cells in the primordial germ cells of the ovary
dysfunction of the tumor suppressor gene trc8/rnf139
transgenerational epigenetic inheritance from hazardous environmental substances (plastics, pesticides, dioxins)
risk_factors: young age (most common in 15-19 year old women, 75% incidence rate for women <30 years)
diagnosis: serum tumor marker test (elevated alpha-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin, lactate dehydrogenase, alkaline phosphatase, cancer antigen 125)
transvaginal ultrasonography (heteroechoic mass with sharp borders and high vascularization)
computed tomography (lobular pattern of the tumor, compartmentalized solid mass with enhancing septa)
palpation or biopsies of lymph nodes (para-aortic, iliac, inguinal)
treatments: hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (hipec) with docetaxel and cisplatin

diseases.summary: Pancreatic cancer arises when cells in the pancreas, a glandular organ behind the stomach, begin to multiply out of control and form a mass. These cancerous cells have the ability to invade other parts of the body. Pancreatic cancer usually begins in the cells that produce digestive juices. Some risk factors for developing pancreatic cancer include smoking, long-term diabetes, chronic pancreatitis, and certain hereditary disorders. It is often found late and spreads quickly, making it hard to treat. The pancreas is a gland behind your stomach and in front of your spine. It produces the juices that help break down food and the hormones that help control blood sugar levels.
risk_factors: high levels of red meat consumption
meat cooked at very high temperatures
excessive alcohol consumption (indirectly via chronic pancreatitis)
symptoms: yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice)
diagnosis: imaging tests (ct scan, endoscopic ultrasound, mri, positron emission tomography, abdominal ultrasound)
treatments: nuclear medicine therapy (radiolabeled peptides or hormones)
liver transplantation (in cases of liver metastasis)
subtypes: undifferentiated carcinoma with osteoclast-like giant cells

diseases.summary: Pancreatoblastoma is a rare type of pancreatic cancer that mainly occurs in childhood and has a relatively good prognosis. It is a tumor that can be quite large and is characterized by the presence of squamoid nests and at least two cell types: cells with acinar differentiation and cells forming small squamoid nests.
diagnosis: histopathology showing acinar, ductal or neuroendocrine differentiation

diseases.summary: A rare neuroendocrine neoplasm that can develop at various body sites. When found in the adrenal gland, they are referred to as pheochromocytomas. They are rare tumors, with an overall estimated incidence of 1 in 300,000. About 75% of paragangliomas are sporadic, the remaining 25% are hereditary.
causes: mutations of the genes for the succinate dehydrogenase (sdhd, sdha, sdhc, sdhb)
symptoms: hearing loss (in glomus tympanicum and jugulare)
cranial nerve palsies (e.g., vagus nerve, hypoglossal nerve, spinal accessory nerve)
diagnosis: tests of blood, urine, or saliva for hormone levels

diseases.summary: Parathyroid carcinoma is a rare cancer that forms in the parathyroid glands, which are responsible for producing parathyroid hormone (PTH) to regulate calcium and phosphorous levels. It can develop from parathyroid adenoma and is characterized by excessive PTH secretion leading to hypercalcemia.
causes: external radiation exposure (associated, but more common with adenoma)
diagnosis: sestamibi parathyroid scan (intense radioactivity, no washout)
high parathyroid hormone concentration in blood (in those > 40 years)
high levels of hcg (suggestive in context)
treatments: aggressive excision (including thyroid and surrounding tissues if necessary)
calcimimetics (e.g., cinacalcet) to lower calcium levels

diseases.summary: Penile cancer is a rare cancer that develops in the skin or tissues of the penis. It is highly curable when caught early. Symptoms can include abnormal growth, an ulcer or sore, and bleeding or foul-smelling discharge. It can spread to other parts of the body.
causes: hpv-related precursor lesions (squamous hyperplasia, low-grade penile intraepithelial neoplasia, high-grade pin)
symptoms: redness and irritation on the penis
skin thickening on the glans or inner foreskin
treatments: surgery (wide local excision, microsurgery, laser surgery, circumcision, amputation/penectomy)
subtypes: squamous-cell carcinoma (basaloid, warty, mixed warty-basaloid, verrucous, papillary, other scc mixed, sarcomatoid carcinomas)

diseases.summary: Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor that usually starts in the cells of one of your adrenal glands. Although they are usually benign, pheochromocytomas often cause the adrenal gland to make too many hormones, leading to high blood pressure and symptoms such as headaches, sweating, pounding of the heart, shakiness, and paleness. It is part of the paraganglioma (PGL) family of neuroendocrine tumors. These tumors can release catecholamines into the bloodstream, causing symptoms like hypertension, tachycardia, sweating, and headaches. Pheochromocytoma is sometimes part of multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome (MEN).
causes: genetic mutations (e.g., in sdhx genes, ret proto-oncogene, vhl, nf1, hif2a)
risk_factors: succinate dehydrogenase subunit x (sdhx) genetic variants
diagnosis: immunohistochemistry (chromogranin-a, synaptophysin, gata3, sox10, s100, sdhb, inhibin a, caix, th, dbh, chat, ki67)
treatments: surgery (surgical resection, laparoscopic adrenalectomy, open procedure)
chemotherapy (cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and dacarbazine - cvd; temozolomide - tmz)
targeted therapy (tyrosine kinase inhibitors - tkis, belzutifan, selpercatinib)
radionuclide therapy (iodine-131 meta-iodobenzylguanadine - mibg, peptide receptor radionuclide therapy - prrt)

diseases.summary: Pituitary adenomas are tumors that occur in the pituitary gland, a pea-sized gland at the base of the brain that acts as the 'master control gland' by producing hormones affecting growth and other glands. Most pituitary tumors are benign and often asymptomatic. However, hormone-producing tumors can disrupt hormonal balance, leading to endocrine diseases like Cushing's syndrome and hyperthyroidism. Symptoms can include headaches, vision problems, nausea, vomiting, and issues related to hormone overproduction or underproduction. Treatment options include surgery, medication, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.
causes: duplications in chromosome xq26.3 including gpr101 gene (x-lag syndrome)
risk_factors: infection with human t-lymphotropic virus type 1 (htlv-1)
symptoms: problems caused by the production of too many hormones
central diabetes insipidus (severe thirst, excessive dilute urine)
diagnosis: complete medical history and physical examination
laboratory evaluations for hormone hypersecretion and hypopituitarism
treatments: medication (cabergoline, bromocriptine, somatostatin receptor ligands like octreotide or lanreotide, pegvisomant, ketoconazole, metyrapone, osilodrostat, etomidate, mitotane, pasireotide, mifepristone)
radiation therapy (external beam, proton beam, stereotactic radiosurgery)

diseases.summary: Plasma cell leukemia (PCL) is a plasma cell dyscrasia, a disease involving the malignant degeneration of plasma cells. It is the terminal and most aggressive form of these dyscrasias, constituting 2% to 4% of all plasma cell malignancies. PCL can present as primary (in patients without prior history of plasma cell dyscrasia) or secondary (in patients previously diagnosed with multiple myeloma). It is an extremely serious, life-threatening, and therapeutically challenging disease.
causes: development of excessively high number of genetic abnormalities in plasma cells, precursor b cells, or plasmablasts
genetic instability due to acquired abnormalities including gene mutations, single nucleotide polymorphisms, deletions, duplications, translocations, and changes in gene expression
abnormalities affecting wnt signaling pathway, cell cycle regulation, rna metabolism, protein folding, and cadherin-related cell adherence
progressive development of genetic abnormalities leading from monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance to smoldering multiple myeloma, overt myeloma cancer, and ultimately secondary pcl
symptoms: pathologically high levels of monoclonal plasma cells in bone marrow
malignant plasma cell-secreted circulating monoclonal myeloma protein (igg, iga, light chain, or none)
high levels of serum lactate dehydrogenase
extensive disease with malignant plasma cell infiltrations in organs
failures of bone marrow and other organs
toxic effects of prior treatments (in secondary pcl)
diagnosis: presence of >2 billion plasma cells per liter of blood
presence of >20% of nucleated blood cells being plasma cells
values of 0.5 billion or 5% circulating plasma cells (suggested therapeutic criterion)
flow cytometry immunophenotyping of blood cells to detect clonal phenotypes of plasma cells (e.g., cd138+, cd38+, cd19, cd45+/- phenotype)
treatments: vcmp regimen (vincristine, carmustine, melphalan, prednisone alternating with vincristine, carmustine, doxorubicin, prednisone)
maintenance regimen of lenalidomide, bortezomib, and dexamethasone
consolidation/maintenance with immunomodulator agents plus a proteasome inhibitor (e.g., ixazomib, carfilzomib)

diseases.summary: Primary peritoneal cancer (PPC) is a cancer of the cells lining the peritoneum, or abdominal cavity. It is histomorphologically and molecular biologically similar to serous carcinomas, including ovarian serous carcinoma, and is often considered one entity with ovarian cancer, fallopian tube cancer, and uterine serous carcinoma. It usually affects women and is diagnosed after the age of 60.
causes: association with vascular endothelial growth factor
risk_factors: inherited brca1 or brca2 gene mutations
symptoms: pain in the abdomen or pelvis
swelling in the abdomen or pelvis
feeling of pressure in the abdomen or pelvis
sudden or frequent urge to urinate

diseases.summary: Prostate cancer is a type of cancer that forms in the prostate, a gland in the male reproductive system. It is one of the most common cancers in men and often grows slowly, but can sometimes grow quickly and spread to other parts of the body. The disease is characterized by the uncontrolled growth of cells in the prostate.
causes: genetic changes that occur during a person's lifetime
accumulation of genetic mutations to the dna of cells in the prostate
mutations affecting genes involved in cell growth, replication, cell death, and dna damage repair
gene fusion between tmprss2 and the oncogene erg
symptoms: problems urinating (weak stream, difficulty starting, frequent urination, nocturia, pain or burning during urination)
pain in lower back, hips, or pelvis
lymphedema (swelling in genitals or lower limbs)
diagnosis: imaging tests (ultrasound, mri, ct scan, psma scan, bone scintigraphy)
treatments: radiation therapy (intensity-modulated radiation therapy, brachytherapy, external beam radiotherapy)
hormone therapy (androgen deprivation therapy, gnrh agonists, gnrh antagonists)

diseases.summary: Retinoblastoma is a rare and aggressive cancer that develops from immature cells in the retina, the light-detecting tissue of the eye. It is the most common primary malignant intraocular cancer in children, with the majority of cases detected in children under three years old. While survival rates are high in developed countries, affected children may experience vision loss or require eye removal. The disease can be hereditary, linked to genetic defects, or sporadic, caused by congenital mutations.
causes: congenital mutation in chromosome 13 gene 13q14 (retinoblastoma protein)
symptoms: whitish, translucent mass in the eye

diseases.summary: Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is a highly aggressive form of cancer that develops from mesenchymal cells that have failed to fully differentiate into myocytes of skeletal muscle. It is the most common soft-tissue sarcoma in children and the third most common solid tumor in children. RMS can occur in any soft-tissue site but is primarily found in the head, neck, orbit, genitourinary tract, genitals, and extremities. Prognosis is closely tied to the location of the primary tumor and the subtype.
causes: mesenchymal cells failing to differentiate into myocytes of skeletal muscle
risk_factors: inherited disorders such as li-fraumeni syndrome
symptoms: lump or swelling in soft tissue
rapidly enlarging, firm mass in extremity tissue
diagnosis: immunohistochemical staining for muscle-specific proteins (myogenin, muscle-specific actin, desmin, d-myosin, myod1)

diseases.summary: Salivary gland cancer is a rare type of head and neck cancer that forms in the tissues of the salivary glands. These glands produce saliva, which aids in chewing, swallowing, digestion, and oral hygiene. The cancer may not cause symptoms initially, but can manifest as a lump or swelling in the ear, cheek, jaw, lip, or inside the mouth, along with potential fluid drainage from the ear, difficulty swallowing or opening the mouth, and facial numbness, weakness, or pain. Malignant growths can involve nerves, leading to facial nerve paralysis, pain, and paresthesias. Fixation of a lump, ulceration, and induration of the mucosa are also indicators of malignancy.
symptoms: lump in ear, cheek, jaw, lip, or inside the mouth
fixation of lump to overlying skin
subtypes: salivary gland adenocarcinoma, not otherwise specified
extranodal marginal zone b cell lymphoma

diseases.summary: Uterine cancer is a cancer that forms in tissues of the uterus, also known as the womb. There are two main types: endometrial cancer, which begins in the cells lining the uterus (endometrium), and uterine sarcoma, a rarer, more aggressive cancer that starts in the muscle or other tissues of the uterus.
risk_factors: estrogen-only hormone replacement therapy (hrt) after menopause
past radiation therapy to the pelvis (for uterine sarcoma)

diseases.summary: Serous tumors are neoplasms that typically have papillary to solid formations of tumor cells with crowded nuclei. They commonly arise on the modified Mllerian-derived serous membranes that surround the ovaries in females, accounting for approximately a quarter of all ovarian tumors. Rarely, serous tumors can arise from within the uterus (uterine serous carcinoma), other parts of the peritoneum, or even in locations like the lungs.
causes: unknown for uterine serous carcinoma, but it is classified as a type ii endometrial cancer and does not develop from endometrial hyperplasia or is hormone-sensitive.
originating from the fimbriated end of the fallopian tube has emerged as an origin for many high-grade serous carcinomas.
diagnosis: pathology dissection protocols such as the see-fim protocol (for identifying early serous cancers and precancers in the fallopian tube)
treatments: surgery (curative for benign tumors, likely curative for other low grade tumors)
treatment for low grade serous tumors
treatment for high grade serous tumors

diseases.summary: Skin cancer is a type of cancer that arises from the skin cells, characterized by the uncontrolled growth of abnormal cells that can invade or spread to other parts of the body. It is the most common form of cancer globally. The primary cause is prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun or tanning devices, which damages skin cell DNA. There are three main types: basal-cell skin cancer (BCC), squamous-cell skin cancer (SCC), and melanoma. BCC and SCC are collectively known as nonmelanoma skin cancer (NMSC). BCC typically grows slowly and rarely spreads, while SCC is more likely to spread. Melanoma is the most aggressive and dangerous type. Diagnosis is usually made by biopsy and histopathological examination. Treatment depends on the type, location, and stage of the cancer, and commonly involves surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, photodynamic therapy, and biologic therapy.
causes: prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (uv) radiation from the sun
exposure to uv radiation from tanning devices
uvb radiation via direct dna damage (for bcc and scc)
uva radiation via indirect dna damage (for melanoma)
hpv infections (increase risk of squamous-cell skin cancer)
deliberate exposure of sensitive skin to sunlight
risk_factors: spending a lot of time in the sun
poor immune function (e.g., from medications or hiv/aids)
having moles (especially larger ones or those that change)
ozone depletion (contributes to increased uv exposure)
symptoms: changes in the skin that do not heal
changes in existing moles (size, shape, color, irregular edges, bleeding, itching)
painful lesion that itches or burns
large brownish spot with darker speckles
raised, smooth, pearly bump on sun-exposed skin (bcc)
small blood vessels visible within the tumor (bcc)
crusting and bleeding in the center of the tumor (bcc)
red, scaling, thickened patch on sun-exposed skin (scc)
firm hard nodules with scaly top (scc)
various colors from shades of brown to black (melanoma)
pink, red, or fleshy colored moles (amelanotic melanoma)
rapidly growing, non-tender red, purple, or skin-colored bumps (merkel cell carcinomas)
treatments: targeted therapy (e.g., braf inhibitors, mek inhibitors)
subtypes: skin sarcomas (e.g., angiosarcoma, dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, kaposi's sarcoma, leiomyosarcoma)

diseases.summary: Soft tissue sarcoma (STS) is a malignant tumor that develops in soft tissues such as muscles, tendons, fat, and blood vessels. There are many subtypes, often characterized by a slow-growing, painless mass. As tumors grow, they can press on nerves and organs, causing pain or breathing difficulties. Diagnosis is typically made via biopsy, and treatment options include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and targeted drug therapy.
causes: exposure to certain chemicals (e.g., chlorophenols, phenoxy herbicides, vinyl chloride)
genetic alteration of the tp53 gene (li-fraumeni syndrome)
inherited diseases (e.g., neurofibromatosis type i, inherited retinoblastoma)
human herpesvirus 8 (in kaposi sarcoma, though distinct from typical sts)
risk_factors: exposure to high doses of radiation
symptoms: pain or soreness (as tumor presses against nerves and muscles)
diagnosis: pathological examination of tissue under a microscope
histological grading systems (national cancer institute system, french federation of cancer centers sarcoma group system)
treatments: immunotherapy (e.g., atezolizumab for alveolar soft part sarcoma)

diseases.summary: Stomach cancer, also known as gastric cancer, is a malignant tumor of the stomach that develops in the lining of the stomach due to abnormal cell growth. It is often diagnosed late due to non-specific early symptoms, leading to a generally poor prognosis. The cancer can spread to other parts of the body, including the liver, lungs, bones, lining of the abdomen, and lymph nodes. Globally, it is a significant cause of cancer-related deaths.
causes: genetic syndromes (e.g., hereditary diffuse gastric cancer)
risk_factors: dietary factors (fried foods, processed meat, red meat, brackens)
symptoms: bloating of the stomach after meals
diagnosis: blood tests (complete blood count, fecal occult blood test)
imaging tests (ct scan, pet scan, abdominal ultrasound)
treatments: surgery (gastrectomy, endoscopic mucosal resection, endoscopic submucosal dissection)
chemotherapy (e.g., 5-fluorouracil, cisplatin, epirubicin, etoposide, docetaxel, oxaliplatin, capecitabine, irinotecan)
targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab for her2-overexpressing tumors)
treatment of h. pylori infection (for malt lymphomas)
subtypes: lymphomas (e.g., extranodal marginal zone b-cell lymphomas, diffuse large b-cell lymphomas)

diseases.summary: Testicular cancer is a cancer that develops in the tissues of one or both testicles, which are part of the male reproductive system and are responsible for making male hormones and sperm. It is rare but highly treatable and usually curable, with high survival rates, especially when detected early.
causes: infection with human t-lymphotropic virus type 1 (htlv-1)
risk_factors: age (most common in men between 20 and 39, but can occur at any age)
symptoms: painless lump or swelling in either testicle
change in how the testicle feels
dull ache in the lower abdomen or groin
sudden build-up of fluid in the scrotum
pain or discomfort in a testicle or in the scrotum
feeling of heaviness in the scrotum
diagnosis: blood tests (including tumor markers like alpha-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin, and ldh-1)
inguinal orchiectomy (surgical removal of the testicle for tissue examination)
ct scans (for staging and detecting metastases)
pregnancy test (to detect high levels of chorionic gonadotropin)
treatments: high-dose chemotherapy with stem cell support

diseases.summary: Thymoma is a rare tumor originating from the epithelial cells of the thymus, a small organ in the upper chest. It can be asymptomatic or cause symptoms due to compression of surrounding organs. Thymomas are frequently associated with neuromuscular and autoimmune disorders.
causes: tumor originating from epithelial cells of the thymus
treatments: neoadjuvant chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy (for invasive/large tumors)

diseases.summary: Thyroid cancer is a cancer that starts in the tissues of the thyroid gland, a small, butterfly-shaped gland in the front of the neck that makes hormones controlling metabolism. It is a disease in which cells grow abnormally and have the potential to spread to other parts of the body. Most cases are asymptomatic at diagnosis.
causes: radiation treatments to the head or neck as a child
mutations in the genes for mena and men2b
risk_factors: exposure to certain types of radiation
young age at time of radiation exposure
symptoms: hoarseness or other changes to voice
pain in the anterior region of the neck
feeling of something in the throat
subtypes: thyroid gland noninvasive follicular neoplasm with papillary-like nuclear features

diseases.summary: Urethral cancer is a rare cancer that originates from the urethra, the tube that allows urine to pass out of the body. It is more common in men and its incidence rises after the age of 75. The most common type is papillary urothelial carcinoma.
causes: prolonged irritations of the urethra due to urinary catheterization
symptoms: weak or interrupted flow of urine
lump or thickness in the perineum or penis
pain in the groin or vaginal area
diagnosis: examination of the urethra with a cystoscope
treatments: surgery (open excision, electro-resection with flash, laser surgery, cystourethrectomy, cystoprostatectomy, anterior body cavity, incomplete or basic penectomy surgery)

diseases.summary: Uterine sarcoma is a rare, aggressive cancer that begins in the muscle or other tissues of the uterus. It is harder to treat than endometrial cancer and can spread quickly. It is a malignant tumor arising from the smooth muscle or connective tissue of the uterus.
causes: past treatment with radiation therapy to the pelvis
risk_factors: estrogen-only hormone replacement therapy (hrt) after menopause

diseases.summary: Vaginal cancer is a rare form of cancer that develops in the tissue of the vagina. Primary vaginal cancer originates from the vaginal tissue, most frequently squamous cell carcinoma, but primary vaginal adenocarcinoma, sarcoma, and melanoma have also been reported. Secondary vaginal cancer involves the metastasis of a cancer that originated in a different part of the body and is more common. It often can be cured if found and treated in early stages.
risk_factors: abnormal cells in the vagina, cervix, or uterus
symptoms: vaginal bleeding that is not your period
bleeding that is longer than normal
frequent or urgent need to urinate
diagnosis: imaging (ultrasound or mri) for surveillance (not recommended without symptoms)
subtypes: vaginal germ cell tumors (teratoma, endodermal sinus tumor)

diseases.summary: Vulvar cancer is a rare type of cancer that forms in a woman's external genitals, called the vulva. It usually grows slowly over several years, often starting as precancerous cells (vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia or VIN).
causes: chronic inflammation or autoimmunity affecting the vulvar area
risk_factors: history of vulvar or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia
prior history of pre-invasive or invasive cervical cancer
symptoms: bleeding that is not your period
changes in the vulvar skin (color changes, growths, ulcer)
itching, burn, or bleeding on the vulva that does not go away
changes in the color of the skin of the vulva (redder or whiter)
skin changes in the vulva (rash or warts)
sores, lumps, or ulcers on the vulva that do not go away

diseases.summary: Wilms tumor is a rare type of kidney cancer that typically occurs in children, causing a tumor on one or both kidneys. It is the most common malignant renal tumor in children. While the majority of cases occur in children without associated genetic syndromes, a minority have congenital abnormalities. The tumor is highly responsive to treatment, with a high cure rate.
